reviews.review: Wonderful surprise. My Son and I traveled to Italy. Rome was our first stop. We were just wandering when we came upon a small piazza where it appeared a wedding was taking place. My son said let's take a look inside the church it looks like other people are going in. So we went in and to our amazement we encountered the most beautiful ceiling fresco. This was by far one of our favorite places. Worth the effort to find.

Stunning. Probably one the best pieces of art that I saw in my short trip to Rome and I had been to the Sistine Chapel too. We came here on a walking tour and was so taken aback with the stunning frescos and art work we came back again for a longer look around. we timed it right as there was to be a wedding a little later and we were able to witness a the small orchestra play a few pieces. All this added to the atmosphere of the visit. Definitely worth a visit.

Stunning church. After visiting the Pantheon nearby, it started to rain. We happened across this church with its doors opened so we ducked in to avoid the storm. We were absolutely blown away by what we saw! This was hands down one of the most beautiful churches we've been to in all of Europe. The ceiling was beautifully painted and gave the illusion of opening up to the heavens. To be honest, I think the artistry rivaled that of the Sistine Chapel. Plus, it had almost no one visiting so we had the place almost to ourselves. A definite "must see" if visiting Rome.

Visit for the fresco painted on the nave ceiling. Andrea Pozzo painted the ceiling fresco and it is fabulous. I recommend reading about the church's interior art and history before visiting so you know what you are looking at. Not the most popular church for visiting in Rome but that's also a good thing.

Spectacular. This incredible church was recommended to us by fellow travelers at our hotel. So glad they shared. It was stunningly beautiful and we preferred it to the overcrowded over priced Vatican. The incredible art and beauty was almost overwhelming . Very near the Pantheon with its excellent street musicians providing a very special atmosphere. Don't miss this site
The ceiling!. The church is beautiful, but what really makes it special is the ceiling. To see also the fake cupola! And the piazza in front of the church s delightful.

Do not leave Rome without a visit. In such a beautiful city, it can seem like sensory overload, however please make time to visit and allow yourselves time to take in the sheer beauty and serenity of this church. We were en route back from visiting the Vatican ( and feeling a little sad as it was almost impossible to truly take in the beauty of the Sistine chapel because of the huge numbers allowed in at one time). Sant' Ignazio is a wonder, just overwhelmingly lovely, and what a joy to find contemporary works here too.Spend an hour here, it'll be one of the highlights of your trip.
Incredible church. A must see as you walk by navona/pantheon, the day I was there a choir was singing making the atmosphere holy and amazing.

Gorgeous. Having gone to a Jesuit institution for undergrad I definitely feel that, amongst the many brilliant churches in Rome, St. Ignatius stands out. We waited for like 45 min after arriving during the lunch hour when it was closed, but were glad we stayed. It's just a short distance from the Pantheon and many other churches worth visiting in the vicinity.

Just beautiful. Yes it's another Roman church. However, as well as being free, not jam-packed and in a convenient place to access other attractions, it is beautiful.The artistry in the ceilings and on the walls is great and the famous model that took a bloke about 25 years to make is pretty interesting too.Definitely worth a visit - you can do it in 15-20 minutes and you're on your way to the next place.

The most important church in Rome for Jesuits and followers of St Ignatius. This is still another great example of the many magnificent churches in Rome. What makes this one soecial is that St Ignatius lived here from1544 until he died in 1556. One will find his tomb, designed by Andrea Del Pozzo in the church. There are many examples of Baroque art throughout, but I believe the real importance of this church is the relationship to Saint Ignatius and his Jesuits.
Andrea Pozze !. One must visit this cathedral order to see what Andrea Pozze did with the ceiling. I've visited this church twice in my life 30 years apart, and each time it is a delight.

Nice surprise . . . .. We stumbled on this church while walking back to our room from the Pantheon. What a pleasant surprise. This was one of the best churches we visited while in Italy. The paintings on the ceiling and walls were superb. The nicest thing about it was that it was almost empty when we were there, which was refreshing after suffering the crowds at the Vatican and the ancient monuments. Highly recommend.

Found this by accident. What a happy surprise.. 4.5 stars. This is another church within a quick walking distance of the Pantheon. We were just wandering around out of curiosity and found this one. I highly recommend dropping into this one. It has a stunning ceiling and wonderful dome that is sure to please nearly anyone.
What a surprise!. We were just walking around the area of the Pantheon and came across this incredible Church. Spectacular ceiling with an incredible optical illusion. A must see!!
Incredible artwork. Be amazed by the incredible 3D artwork at the ceiling and the small dome which is fake. But the religious fresco done by Andrea Pozzo are superior. Just sit and look!

Very Unique Church!. My husband and I spent over two weeks in Italy during our first trip to the country, and we saw a LOT of churches and basilicas. THIS church was actually my husband's favorite and one of the sights he remembers most fondly from our trip.The church is not very high on most tourists' lists, but I was interested in checking it out for the interesting fake dome that I read about. It is really neat to see in person and the ceiling also has a beautiful fresco. I would highly recommend stopping in on your way to/from the Pantheon!

A World Marvel. the "Chiesa di Sant'Ignazio" is a true masterpiece of Humanity. Rome is beautiful everywhere and its 300+ churches testify this, but Sant'Ignazio has SOMETHING MORE...SOMETHING INTIMATELY SPECIAL....when you enter, when you go around, when you stare at basically everything inside, you are caught by a sort of unexplicable Pleasant and Great Emotion.......then....what else to say,,,the "false" cupola....the paintings....the columns (fantastic)....the Altar of San Luigi......All is just OUTSTANDING.....one of the best treasures of the Capital of the World in my humble opinion.
Baroque masterpiece. Located near the Trevi fountain, this beautifully decorated church is fascinating to visit. Many baroque treasures to see.

What a nice surprise.. We popped into the church as it was starting to rain because we were visiting Piazza Navona and the Pantheon that afternoon.What a nice surprise it was. From the outside, one would never expect the interior to be so ornate and beautiful. There was a priest available for confessionals inside a rather modern booth with the green light turned on to indicate that he was available.A must see, especially since it is situated between two of Rome's major landmarks.
Worth a visit.. We came across this church on the way to the Piazza Navona. Certainly worth a visit. Lots of 'trees of life' within the church. Very quiet & peaceful.

Favourite 3D. Sant Ignazio is my personal favourite. This stands out as being particularly spectacular. Look at the ceiling ! its not what you first think... I could spend hours looking at the ceiling !!! Just as good as the Sistine chapel.
Magnificent!. Having been schooled in a Jesuit institution, seeing one with St Ignatius of Loyola, I had a great time going around the area, and the inside of the church as well.

Beautiful frescoes and interior. Chanced upon this church as I was passing by and made it in time for Sunday mass. Beautiful frescoes on the ceiling and can see they have been preserved with effort as colors are still vibrant.

Better experience than the Sistine chapel? I think so.. If you want to see beautiful ceilings in Rome, you've got plenty of options. Sant Ignazio is my personal favourite. I have visited all of the major sites, and this stands out in a good way for a few reasons:1) Free to enter - even during mass you can walk around quietly and enjoy the art;2) not busy at all - the total opposite of the Sistine Chapel;3) The artwork is simply incredible - vibrant frescos with perspective illusions and detailed sculptures.Give yourself at least 30 minutes inside to appreciate everything it has to offer.

Wonderfully imaginative dome. The unwritten rule of Italy is that you must always pop into a church when passing - irrespective of your religious preferences. The tardis effect of these buildings never ceases to amaze. A small door on a building in a labyrinth of streets opens into a massive, richly adorned celebration of eternal life. And so it was that we happened across St Ignatius. However, this one has a quirky feature. It was not permitted to build a dome. Undeterred, they have painted the appearance of a dome onto the flat ceiling. This isn't immediately obvious as you walk down the nave (which marks the point where the perspective is perfect), but once you stand underneath, it clearly looks wrong. But the imagination to do this brings a smile to your face. This is not the only feature of interest. The trompe l'oeil paintings on the ceiling of the nave are beautiful. And after expending all this artistic energy, the restaurant in the piazza outside is well worth a visit for lunch or dinner.

Breathtaking!. My most anticipated visit in Rome, and I was not disappointed. The tromp l'oeil ceilings of lay Jesuit brother, Andrea Pozzo, simply defied belief. Stand on the special marble disc set in the church floor and all the perspectives fall into place. If you find it hard to look up there is a large mirror in the centre of the church which very adequately reflects the masterpiece without recking necks. Read about the fresco's meaning first, then make your visit.

Definitely worth a visit. This is a most beautiful church. I am not a Jesuit or even a catholic but I loved this church. Very beautifully decorated with some famous works of art and trompe d'oeil. There is currently an exhibition of crafted trees each of which has a Christian message, very lovely and actually very peaceful.

A BEAUTIFUL CHURCH THAT HONORS THE JESUITS.. Few churches mean as much to a Jesuit educated person as this San Iganzio in Roma. After of course St. Peter's Basilica and San Giovani in Laterano, this is the place I always return to when I visit.

Amazing Church. We happened upon this church while wandering in Rome (I had read about it ahead of time), and I am so thankful we stopped in!! You are required to wear appropriate dress, and I am thankful they had shawls to lend ladies with bare shoulders. The artwork and alters inside are magnificent - almost rivaling St. Peter's - so much to take in! Definitely stop in if you have some time, we only took about 15-20 minutes, but you could stay a little longer as well.

More beautiful than St. Peter's?. Well, probably not...but it is a fair question. My guess is that not 1/100th of the people that tour St. Peter's make it over to St. Ignatius. They are the worse for it. It is perhaps the most beautiful church in the world that you can see up close. Grab a quick guidebook online, because the art is worth knowing about (in addition to just marveling at.) A neat added bonus for Catholic visitors: there were confessions on Sunday.Quick hint: the guys taking offering at the door do NOT work for the church. If you are inspired to leave an offering, there is a well-marked place inside.

Another amazing interior!. This cathedral is worth a stop. The interior is entirely stunning - typically lavish for Catholic buildings, with beautifully painted walls, ceilings, chapels etc. Two extra attractions of note here are the stunning use of marble of all colours everywhere, and the main highlight which makes this cathedral stand out from others - the fake rotunda where the naves meet.Story has it that money ran out in the construction, so a flat roof was placed in the area where the cupola should be as a holding design - which never got replaced! It is worthy of note for the artistry on it. A fake perspective as been painted on it to make it look like a real rotunda is there. Of course, this view doesn't work everywhere - it is best walking down the centre of the nave, until you reach a star in the floor of the nave, where the effect starts to become less obvious.Definitely worth a look!

Glorious. This church ranks as possibly the best I've ever been in anywhere in the world. The sheer beauty of the church hits you as soon as you walk in and are faced with the 4 paintings above and behind the main alter, then your eyes are drawn to the "mock dome" although you get the impression of a dome it it a 3d optical illusion and in fact is flat. Definitely worth a longish visit so you have time to take in the beauty of the church.

Stunning.... In my opinion, this church is more beautiful than St. Peter's basilica. We accidently walked by, while we were on our way to Pantheon, and we were just blown away only by its exterior... Came back the last day of our stay and visited the interior. It's just stunning!

Beautiful. Originally we walked past this after taking a few photos outside but changed our minds and we were blown away. Inside this church is the most decorative paintings and sculptures. There are signs about different statues which are every informative.You are not allowed to show your shoulders however they provide scarfs for you to us. It was more beautiful than the Sistine Chapel in my view. Definitely worth a stop.

Amazing church. In our trip to Italy we saw many of the most famous churches you can find. We happened to stumble on to this one and it was one our favorite. If I ever return I will spend more time here.

3D and Imagination is what you need here. The Church is on a sidewalk that leads to the Pantheon. Need to pass by the Vico dei Burrò, which is also known as little Paris, as it was the seat of the Imperial French administration, and buildings are in the style of Paris. The architect when making the square before the church was inspired by the shape of a theatre. Once inside the Church, you will see it is very much unlike many churches around, yes the art is majestic and stunning and there is a bit of spice to it as well. There are over 20 optical illusions around the Church and you are hereby challenged to finding them.
Most beautiful church!. An amazingly beautiful church with excellent artwork that looks like 3D! It should be on everybody's must see list!

Famous for its "dome"!. lovely church near the Trevi Fountain and the Colonna. Take a good look at the 'Dome" from inside---history tells that they ran out of money when it came to constructing the dome. So the 3D effect from within is a trompe d'oeil, famous for its dome illusion by artist Andrea Pozzo.
Amazing. From the outside of this church you would have no idea about the inside. Just amazing. So pretty, so large... beautiful artwork... If you are near there you should go in.

Awesome. We found this place by accident and it was awesome! The best part was the old man inside who was silencing the visitors. Come dressed appropriately otherwise you'll need to wear the scarf of shame! Worth a visit for sure.

Optical Illusions Galore. What a delightful visit to this beautiful and majestic church. The Dome is an Optical Illusion. The 3D effect in the frescoes was breathtaking. It becomes hard to select the churches to visit in Rome (there are so many), but this should be a definite visit.
Beautiful church!. We were walking from the Piazza Navona to the Trevi Fountain and came upon this gorgeous church. I was just delighted that we didn't miss it.
Beautiful Church. Rome has more beautiful churches than just St. Peter's. This is one of them. Check the opening hours which can be subject to midday closure.

The kids loved it!! . Beautiful, interesting and my kids (12/13) loved it. And free ;)
Got there on the way, didn't look much from the outside, my daughter wanted so we went in, was well worth it.

Stunning. The church is absolutely stunning. Truly a must on your visit to Rome. I passed by and went end by chance of luck. Almost couldn't leave. It's breathtaking and stands apart from other beautiful churches in Rome.

What a ceiling!. The ceiling makes you feel that you are staring into infinity.Also the dome is fake and is painted to look higher than it actually is.There should have been a sign which asked people to stand on the yellow discs to get the perfect view of the incredible ceiling.This church is just a few steps away from the Pantheon and is definitely more breathtaking.Don't miss this Church!

Better than the Vatican and less crowded!!!. Ok the Sistine chapel is amazing and not to missed - see my review. But this church (which is free and waaayyy less crowded) is JUST AS IMPRESSIVE. The 3D ceiling is utterly stupefying. Make sure you look at the window over the entrance for the man on the rights fingers that look like they extend beyond the painting. This blew away my nine year old daughter. And stare at the pillars and shuffle across the floor, keeping your eyes on the pillars and watch them move- they lean different ways when you move from one side to the other. These are just two of the many beautiful paintings/ art in this church.Oh- the other thing that blew her mind? The "dome" is not a dome but a flat ceiling but it looks like a dome. It's 3D art long before 3D sidewalk art. You- and your kids- will Love this church. Beautiful!!!!
Impressive. All the good,things previously said about this church are true. So many churches in Rome, so many features, but this one stood out for us. A beautiful chiesa. Well worth a visit.

Masterful Perspective. The ceiling vault was painted by Andrea Pozzo, one of the master of perspective and its tricks and deceits.The masterpiece is the dome: it is a fake: just painted.The external place is a masterpiece in itself.

Beautiful and inspirational. I don't love the baroque period, but I do love the Jesuits. If you love either one, you really ought to go see this church, hidden away quite near the Trevi Fountain. The use of perspective on the ceiling is really remarkable, not just in the much-talked-about false cupola but even more so in the rest of the ceiling. In addition, the side chapels contain some beautiful pieces--the Angels in the chapel of St. Luigi Gonzaga were my favorites-- that convey a real sense of the Jesuit mission as it must have been felt in the 17th century. If you make time for this, you won't regret it.

ceiling goes up to heaven. Walk to the center of the nave and then look up. There is a remarkable illusion that clouds and angels and figures are floating up and up. This is probably the most spectacular of the Italian Baroque ceilings. Beautiful colors also. The church is close to Piazza Navona. The picture I've attached was taken by reversing the lens as in a selfie.

A spectacular jewel in the heart of Rome!. This beautiful church would easily be missed by many if one is not observant of its outer beauty. From the outside, it mimics the facade of St. Peter's Basilica, with its massive columns and larger-than-life letters boldly unscripted at the top front of the church. When one enters, you cannot help but be left open-mouthed by the spectacular 3-D ceiling, marvelously painted in trompe l'ceil technique by the 17th century painter Andrea Pozzo. If you stand at the center where you see a small gold disk, and look up, you will be amazed at how your eyes can be so deceived into seeing a continuous ascent into the heavens of so many characters, giving you a sense of endless open sky from where you stand. Take note of the man's finger's coming out of the window, the one right above the main door. Simply amazing! You look up and know just where the sistine chapel was inspired. Magnificent!

Worth every minute. Sometimes in Rome you enter in a church just to cool down and rest. I am for many mounts in Rome so I am not in a hurry anymore..i enter in this church because I was curious about the painted ceilling which give a 3D sensation that is a Dome there. You have to see this because this picture was made few centuries ago...I cant imagine how was done. Plus, near the entrance on right hand you can see all the churches in the world made by plastic in an impresive maquette finished in 30 years.

Stunning Jesuit Church. This is just a wonderful example of the High Baroque style with sumptuous ceilings, the trompe d`oueil and the side chapels with impressive statues and memorials to saints and popes, especially those in the Jesuit tradition as this is the second Jesuit Church of Rome after the Gesu. The Laudato Si exhibition housed in 2016 was an impressive use of space for telling the themes of the Pope`s encyclycal on the environment in a series of trees made of metal.
Another beautiful church. Another nice church close to the Piazza Navona. You could take in this site on your visit to the Pantheon.

The Full-On Baroque Experience!. There are a few larger Baroque churches in Rome where illusionistic tricks were used by the architects, sculptors and painters to thrill an audience. Sant'Ignazio is one of these churches. I was constantly staring at the vaults and domes trying to figure out whether I was looking at real space or painted space, sculpted figures or painted figures, etc. Doing this will make you giddy, and perhaps even euphoric!The largest ceiling painting is more-or-less in the central part of the church, and shows architecture reaching up to an open sky, with figures tumbling down into the church space. If you stand at a certain spot on the floor, you'll get the full effect---of infinite space! The same artist also painted a "dome interior" that looks like it's very high. If you look at it from a certain angle, it's surprising to see that it's quite shallow.The church is absolutely dripping with gold, silver, bronze, marble, stucco, etc. It's really difficult to isolate any single object. Everything is overscaled, which isn't to everyone's taste.This was the only church I was in where I saw the custodian at the door turn away some young women for inappropriate attire. Usually there'll be a supply of large shawls that could be given to women to cover up---but not here!

An unexpected surprise awaits you in here!. After walking and touring around Rome for a day in the hot sun, my husband and I found this interesting looking Roccoco church. Curiosity peaked our interest and we walked in to this church. Free to enter, we passed through the doors and gawped in awe at the beautiful arches, colours and paintings around the church. The most amazing thing, I think, was the ceiling. The fresco painting was spectacular. Don't forget to look for the cupola - you'll be amazed at the allusion.
Beautiful Jesuit Church. This is a beautiful church well worth the visit. It's located near the Pantheon. It is one of the Jesuit churches in Rome.
Definitely worth going in. A Baroque church with a very unique ceiling that moves as you do.Would definitely recommend stopping and here while you are walking through this area of Rome

Be prepared to be surprised. We walked past this church on the way from the Pantheon to the Trevi Fountain without giving it a glance. On the way back we thought we may as well pop our head in for a quick look and wow, were we glad we did. We didn't make it the Cistene Chapel during our Rome visit but the artwork on the ceiling of this church and the size and variety of things to see inside made us feel as if we'd been magically transported there. It truly is impressive and remarkably quiet inside - probably because most people will simply walk past the average looking facade without a clue what's hidden inside. I'd thoroughly recommend popping in if in the area.
Wonderful Art!. San Ignazio is one of the many "smaller" churches in Rome with excellent art. Along with its sister church (Gesu) the ceiling in San Ignazio is quite a sight. Worth a stop!

A wonderful church. I have been in Rome many times but this was the first time I visited this church.The thing that surprised me was the "coupola"that it was very dark,almost all black.The fruit trees inside the church had their own meanings.the thing I do not know is if the trees were an exhibition,or they are always there.If so,you better visit it

A hidden gem! . We actually found this church by accident, we were walking from the Trevi Fountain to the Pantheon and sat on some steps for some shade and a wee break. There was a poster outside advertising something so I sent my husband in to see if it was worth taking the children in. He came back out and said WOW! And wow is absolutely the word to describe it. It is a stunning church, with so much to see, and so much amazing art. It's a hidden gem and absolutely worth seeking it out for a visit. As its off the beaten track it's pretty quiet too, which makes it so peaceful and you can really take your time to look around. There is also a great wee stall selling gifts and cards etc, we bought quite a few gifts here as they were really well priced and beautiful. You can light up the dome with a €1 donation in a special machine, we would recommend doing this as it makes it much clearer and stays lit for ages! I can honestly say we enjoyed this church more than the Sistine Chapel! So much so we visited twice!

It made me cry!. You don't have to be religious to appreciate how stunningly beautiful this church is.We just popped our heads round the door and it took my breath away, while my friends walked round, I had to just sit and reflect on it for a while as it took my breath away and made me cry. I don't know why, it just did.This is one of the most lovely churches I have been in and so very interesting. Its not just a church for show, local people were there and a tiny little lady with the sweetest smile was at the table handing out scarves if you didn't have one to cover your shoulders. The whole experience was one of joy, and my friends all felt the same too. Please visit.

Stunning. We stumbled across this place when seeking shelter from the rain and we are glad that we did.We are not religious by any stretch of the imagination but you can't help but be moved by the beauty of the interior of this building. Stunning paintings and statues and remember to look up...you wont be disappointed.A good tip - remember that shoulders must always be covered in religious buildings like this.

The false dome ceiling. I found this site googling cool things to see in Rome. I really enjoyed the ceiling with the optical illusion of a dome painted on a flat surface. The rest of the paintings and decorations in the church were also beautiful.

Beautiful.. The artwork is incredible. Give yourself time to sit and appreciate all that you see. Remember, this is an active church with real parishioners. Be respectful of the space. Loud tourists with selfie sticks diminish the beauty and disturb the meditation of all.

Beauty, art, and faith in one place. For anyone who loves great art and religious history, Sant'Ignazio is a must. I have found that there are always visitors to this special church. I would suggest that Sant'Ignazio and its brother church, the Church of the Gesu be visited in order to see the similarities and differences of these two Jesuit churches.

Amazing!. One of my favourite churches that I visit every time when I travel to Rome. The church was completed in 1626, for the decoration a lot of different precious stones was used. But the main feature is the cupola - or the cupola that was planned but never built. Instead, the dome is painted - a prespective painting that really can fool your eyes. To visit this church is really a must for everyone travelling to Rome.

Without doubt one of the most beautiful places we've ever seen. We bumped into this church walking east/west toward the Spanish Steps about a 1/2 km north. How lucky were we? This place is magical. The art is representative of the greatest Rome has to offer. Check out the high dome ceiling which is actually flat and an optical illusion created with paint. I can not recommend a place more. If there was a 10 star option here, I'd check it in a flash.

An amazing cathedral of the beaten path.. I thought this church was incredible impressive. NO fee, but donations accepted. DO NOT give donations at the door. We had a nicely dressed imposter trying to collect money.

Ethereal Ceiling. The Sant' Ignazio di Loyola is known for its ethereal ceiling. This church is built to commemorate the founder of the Jesuit order in XVII century with gilded ornaments, marble reliefs, and remarkable frescoes. Also, admire the church's Baroque façade.

Seriously mind blowing. This needs to be on your itinerary if you're interested in amazing art. The ceiling is an absolute triumph of perspective painting and is visually astounding; I would almost say that it is more impressive than the Sistine Chapel. You also won't have to beat any crazy lines or pay for a tour.

A special surprise. A must visit. Beautiful church with paintings on the ceiling. There is one particular surprise when you look up which is quite interesting. I won't ruin it for you. A must see for yourself. Enjoy

amazing art. there is no need to describe the churches of rome..they are all amazing and full of art! this one surprise me cause a lot of people doesn t considere it..there is so much to see in this beautiful city!

A great surprise.. From the outside you would not believe the magnificance of this church. We were stunned by the beauty inside. Such an unimposing portico in a very quiet piazza which was marvellous.

Beautiful respite, very quiet, airconditioned . This is the place I will remember most from my trip to Rome. This Jesuit church is beautifully elegant in its architecture, artwork and atmosphere. There are plenty of plain walls which really showed of the stunning artwork on the ceilings. Not bad for a church built in the 1600's We came here exhausted after a day walking around a very packed Rome. It was a lovely escape to sit quietly and admire the artwork without huge groups and tour guides with flags. There was some modern metal sculpture exhibits too. They sat cleverly next to the old church frescos. This is a small church that oozed a cool welcome to a tired tourist.
My favourite!. I thought the frescos were outstanding! This was one of my favourite churches in all of Rome. Less crowded than many of the other well known churches, it's worth a look and free too!

Beautiful church - neat place to celebrate mass. We went to mass in Italian on Saturday evening. It was a neat experience for the entire family. The church has air-conditioning which was a bonus on the 97 degree day. Beautiful church and great history for any Jesuit-educated people.

A Hidden Gem. I'm not a church-going person but I have visited many churches across Europe to enjoy their history, architecture and incredible feats of building, but was totally unprepared for the marvels that lay within this unassuming building.The church is huge and covered in magnificent paintings that capture and enthral you. This has to be my favourite church in Rome, there's much to see here and worth seeking out, it's peaceful and yet moving, you will not be disappointed.
Breathtaking.. Went to this Church after great reviews on tripadvisor. We were not disappointed. The ceilings were unbelievably beautiful. The whole place is gorgeous from the floors to the roof.

Amazing and Overwhelming. After being at the Vatican in the morning we visited here later in the afternoon. I was more overwhelmed by its beauty than in the more famous places. It was quiet and relaxed and the art and beauty of the place made me sit and almost have a little cry!My top place in Rome next to the Colosseum.

Amazing ceiling. Our super tour guide Max took us here, and while the whole church is supremely beautiful, the ceiling deserves special mention. The paintings here are just gorgeous (my husband liked them better than the Sistine Chapel) and the whole effect was just breathtaking.
Most beautiful church in Rome. This is amazing. The most amazing experience. Most peaceful feeling just walking inside this church. Absolutely stunningly painted ceiling.

Drive around Rome. This is my husband's favorite church in Rome. The ceilings are done in 3D and there is a mirror on the floor to appreciate this. It is centrally located and not too far from the Gesu church, Loyola' resting place.
So Beautiful. My husband went to a Jesuit school so this had special meaning for us. The Church is so beautiful we could have stayed for hours.
It is super beautiful. This church is very beautiful , although it doesn't come in the book guides as a main attraction. You should visit it.

Optical Trap!. Not only it was one of the most remarkable churches we've visited in Rome, but thanks to our guide Stefano we realized it was also one of the most quizical. We were there around 7pm and (closing time) it was somewhat spooky however pay attention to the dome. The truth is - there is no dome but the optical illusion of it instead.

Most beautiful church in Rome. This is most beautiful church in the world that I have visited. If you have to visit 1 church in Rome, then this is it! It doesn't get a lot of importance, no security etc. Amazing architecture!!!!

Yes--Hidden gem!. Noticed that this is a common comment of other reviewers--and rightly so! You know that experience when you are walking to a particular location and you stumble upon an incredible "new find". The Chiesa di Sant'Ignazio di Loyola is IT. This un-celebrated cathedral has a very unassuming facade, but once you step inside--prepare to be amazed. The frescoes can be compared to any of the "tourist" cathedrals, and the ceiling features more artificial domes per meter than I have previously seen. (Necessitated by the neighboring cathedrals' insistence that the founding society have no "competing domes".) The featured fresco treats the eye to Christian world history-right up to the second coming.

Beautiful church with interesting details. This was a hidden gem on our tour of Rome. While not especially imposing from the outside, the inside of this church is quite beautiful. There also was a very nice art exhibition while we were there. One of the coolest aspects of the church are the various trompe l'oeil effects on the ceiling of the church -- necessary because of a shortage of funds to fully build out a dome or gabled roof. Magnificent ceiling. When entering this church you do not expect such a large church with lots of light and high celings. To me these celings were amazing, completely painted in vivid colours. You can look at the different angels, people, animals....etc for a very long and still find something new to discover!
Hidden gem.. On our way to Trevi we decided to have a look here...not knowing what was inside. Eye candy is what we found. Going just a few days to Rome? Include this place.
Lovely Ceiling. This is a lovely church among many such churches in Rome. The unusual ceiling perspective s worth the very short walk after you visit the Pantheon.

Amazing frescoes and so much more!. When visiting Rome, you will find one breathtaking church after another. It truly is amazing, while wandering from the Pantheon to the Trevi Fountain, we found this incredible church on accident and we were so glad we did! It was remarkable. While being somewhat unassuming from the outside, the moment you walk in, you're in awe of the beauty and incredible detail seen throughout this impressive place of worship. Take the time to take in the wonderful frescoes, the intricately detailed dome, the countless number of carvings and even the incredible marble floors. From floor to ceiling, this church is truly incredible! Be sure to spend a fair amount of time to really check out the whole place and take in all of its wonders. Stunning trompe'd'oeil ceiling. This was a real find; beautiful church building with stunning artwork by Andrea Pozzo, with the use of perspective and tricks extraordinary. The fake dome is amazing, and the ceiling painting is both beautiful but technically wonderful too.
Amazing. Go early in the day and spend some time. This is an amazing cathedral. Visit every little nook and cranny.
Impressive church among so many in Rome. The fake cupola is impressive and definitely worth it, among all the other churches/cathedrals in Rome

Well worth a visit. Perhaps not a "major" site for visitors to Rome but an oasis of peace and a feast for the senses. It is also a very cool place of respite from the searing heat of summer!

Incredible - don't miss it when in Rome. We were tipped on visiting this church by a Rome native, and he was right. The ceiling painted in such unbelievable perspective, I still can't believe the church is not 3 times taller than it is.
Fabulous. Made a bee line to here to see its painted 3D effect Dome which is just exceptional..Just trying to take a photograph of it proved more difficult as so dark..A must to see.

amazing. I absolutely love this church. It has all the WOW factor of the sistine chapel without the thousands of tourists. I make sure I bring people to see it every time I am in Rome. It's so worth the visit.

Interesting.... and detailed "maquette" of this church can be seen as soon as we enter the building on your right. Look at the fake dome (press the light by inserting a coin). Very curious 3D painting!
True beauty. So glad we did not miss it. A church full of marvellous paintings and an exhibit of various types of trees. NOT TO MISS!
Wonderful paintings. You will be amazed at the majesty of the painting of Pozzo, and the "trompe l'oeil" of one of the cupola.
Glad We Didn't Miss it. Very picturesque little church in Rome. The ceilings were absolutely beautiful and we were glad we did not miss it.

Fantastic - well worth visiting. The ceilings in this church are fantastic. The marble alters in the side chapels are also very beautiful and decorative. Well worth dropping into here. Also, there is no entry fee.
Awesome place. Not very famous but yet one of those places that you will be glad to remember for its greatness and majesty
amazing architecture. very nice place, relaxing and soothing, recommend it to everyone, we like it a lot, amazing architecture
Over Rated. I had gone to see it considering it's review and all religion temple. As the temple made is a model n can not be viewed all side. 3 side view is blocked. Not worth visit.

wonderful. having spent time in the crowds at the vatican the quiet of this place was a treat in itself - so beautiful and atmospheric - wonderful art - peaceful enough to allow thought - working as a place of prayer and confession but also hosting an art exhibition and a free concert in the evening. wonderful.

Seriously beautiful church with tremendously detailed artwork.. One of the prettiest churches in room and there are many. The main altar is stunning. I'm not sure how long it will be there but there is presently a special exhibit being shown in the church of sculptured trees of life. Don't miss it

Oh my God. Or anny other if you like it. Or none at all. But you must see this church no matter what you belive in because, imho, it is the most beautiful and impressive church I have ever seen from inside. Words or photos could not describe how glorious it is...

Should be on your list. Another little piazza and surprise surprise another church but the interior of this one is special and uncrowded. Make sure you put it on the list.
Better than the St Peters. An impressive shurch with beautiful fresco. Not so crowded as St Peters and much smaller. Worth a visit.
Must see. This is a magnificent church near the in one of the touristic area near pantheon. Entry is free. Strongly recommended, as it was one of the most impressive churches we've seen in Rome.
Amazing church. You have to come her just to see the ceiling if nothing else. The church has a beautiful atmosphere.

Unbelievably Beautiful Church. Walking into this church on my first day in Rome brought tears to my eyes due its sheer beauty. Wonderful little find. Well worth the time as it is a quick visit, not far from the Pantheon. The church's ceilings are actually flat--there is no dome either-but the eye is very well fooled in this church.

Neat church with an interesting ceiling. Make sure if you are near the Pantheon you stop in to this church. The ceiling is a study in the use of perspective in art. On the ground in the center of the church are two golden circles. Stand on the on the one and you are in the perfect position to see elements of the ceiling's art pop out at in almost 3D fashion. move forward to the second circle and you will see how they transformed the flat circular ceiling into an optical illusion making it appear as if there is a dome, even though they ran out of money to build an actual one. Donate a euro in the machine to have it properly lit for full effect!

Calming influence. Well worth popping into as nearby the Pantheon. Impressive ceiling paintings, if not quite up to the standard of the Sistine Chapel (but what is?). Great paintings with optical effects. Wiew the paintings on tje seeling and the fake dome it looks like the figures are springing out the walls

Best ceiling in Rome. Perhaps it's not the one you hear about, or read about, but go here if you're in the area. Initially, you'll think what's all the fuss with the ceilings, but it's all about standing in the correct place to appreciate the perspective. Look on the floor for a yellow/gold stone disc (approx 12" diameter) and stand on it. Look up, and there are the heavens receding above you -it's an illusion. Then, continue walking up towards the altar, and look for a second disc in the floor. Stand on it and look up at the supposed 'dome'. It isn't - it's another optical illusion.

A hidden gem - you won't believe your eyes (really). If you’re walking from the Pantheon to the Trevi Fountain it’s easy to walk past this church without giving it a second glance, but do pop in. Apparently the church’s founders ran out of money and couldn’t afford a real dome.

Beautiful. Really worth a visit. On entrance there is a visual feast of architecture, art and a genuine atmosphere of history which is hard to describe. Magnificent and humbling at the same time.Just visit and you'll see what I mean, it's well worth it.

Beautiful fake dome!. The most special part of this church is the beautifully painted "fake dome" - an optical illusion that seems to be a high dome of the church, but is in fact skilfully painted to look as such. The rest of the church is beautiful too!

Externally a Plain Church, But Internally an Amazing Ceiling. I've been to Rome two times previously but, because of the wealth of sights and attractions, have never entered this place before. I was so glad that we went in and learned some of the history of the place, especially the story behind the amazing ceilings. Apparently, following uproar over the original public monies absorbed in the construction of the church that was more accessible by the wealthy, one of the priests, Ignacio, who was a talented mathematician came up with a budget price scheme to create a magnificant ceiling that wouldn't upset the people further. With clever use of perspective, he devised surface decorations that have created a remarkable three-dimensional effect that, to the ground level observer, appear to be ornate carving and stonework. I can confirm that these are truly remarkable and am not surprised that most of the churchgoers of that time were convinced of their authenticity and were perplexed to understand quite how the church afforded them without drawing on the public purse.
Worth finding . Beautiful church, worth finding. So many people walking past as it's not on the top ten list. easy to find as it's on the street between the other attractions.

Just lovely! Peaceful haven from the crowds.. This church is only 2 minutes from the hustle and bustle of the Pantheon and yet it was peaceful and uncrowded inside. The best church. Wow. This was amazing. The history there is very interesting and the place inside is beautiful. You can light a candle if you wish. The church is free to get in but there are donation boxes

The Larger Jesuit Church!. This large Baroque styled church was built between 1625-50 following the canonization of St. Ignatius of Loyola in1622 and is located on the square bearing his name in the historical center of Rome. He was the founder of the Jesuits and is buried nearby at Chiesa del Gesu which is the smaller Jesuit mother church.The inside has attractive Corinthian pilasters that surround the whole interior. The entire nave ceiling has a spectacular fool-the-eye fresco that was painted by Andrea Pozzo. He also did the cycle of frescoes about the life of St. Ignatius in the broad eastern apse incl. the "Siege of Pamplona" where he gets wounded and "St. Ignatius sends St. Francis Xavier to India" recalling the aggressive missionary work around the world.The ceilings in the right and left transept are also painted by Andrea Pozzo. The side chapels all have richly ornamented altars. The tomb monument of Pope Gregory XV is situated in the chapel next to the presbytery. The large stucco statue of St. Ignatius was made by Camillio Rusconi in1728.
