Amazing Illusion. We entered this church because we passed by, not knowing what to expect. It is definitely not one of the many similar ones as it has most beautiful painted ceiling that creates the 3D dome illusion. Do not miss it.
Very cool fake dome. A very interesting church, elaborate ceiling and a dome that isn't really a dome - painted to look 3-dimensional.
Beautiful church. Thoroughly recommend looking in this beautiful church if you are walking past. The dome, especially, is painted to perfection
Unbelievable inside. We passed this church so many times because on the outside it is so unassuming. Go inside and it is beautiful!! The ceilings are painted in 3D (no glasses required)!

The dome tops it off.. As with many churches in Rome, the ceiling is magnificent but the dome, with its optical illusion is the centrepiece. Like all churches in Rome, it is free to enter and quiet and cool in summer. Take time to really look around!

Slightly Better than the usual Roman Church. There are SO MANY churches in Rome that, honestly, they all start to seem the same. And, let's be honest, nothing compares to St Peters & St Paul's. My favorite part of Sant'Ignazio di Loyola is the painting on the ceiling, which creates a sort of illusion of a dome. I also appreciated the large sculptures in the sections on either side of the altar.
Beautiful church!. We visited this church by chance; we just dropped in while passing by and were not disappointed! In particular, the wooden model church is well worth the visit!
beautiful church. This is a large church with high painted ceilings and beautiful stone work. Not too busy while we were there.

I just love everything in Rome !!. It is free to visit :)Wikipedia; The Church of St. Ignatius of Loyola at Campus Martius (Italian: Chiesa di Sant'Ignazio di Loyola in Campo Marzio, Latin: Ecclesia Santi Ignatii a Loyola in Campo Martio) is a Roman Catholic titular church, of deaconry rank, dedicated to Ignatius of Loyola, the founder of the Society of Jesus, located in Rome, Italy. Built in Baroque style between 1626 and 1650, the church functioned originally as the chapel of the adjacent Roman College, that moved in 1584 to a new larger building and was renamed the Pontifical Gregorian University.[1] The most recent Cardinal of the Titulus S. Ignatii de Loyola in Campo Martio was Cardinal Roberto Tucci, S.J.; he had been its Cardinal Deacon until he became its Cardinal Priest (i.e., opted for the order of cardinal priests, with this church being elevated "pro hac vice" to title).
Love the celling. The celling was like Sistine Chapel. It was quite and peaceful. Good central location. Overall I would go back to this church.

Amazing!!!. After waking through some little wooden doors you were totally smacked in the face with this stunning church! It's huge! Beautiful! Altars, sculptures, art, it has it all I cannot begin to describe this place to do it justice! And to think we nearly walked past!! I'm so glad I visited! You will be too!!
Beautiful Church for St Ignatius of Loyola. Not where the remains are kept of St Ignatius but a lovely and impressive facility. Was found in the vicinity of Trevi Fountain

Beauty and Art beyond Words ..... Your visit to the Church of Sant'Ignazio di Loyola will likely render you speechless with its huge size, art pieces, carved altars, 'curved' ceiling frescoes and multicolored stone floors. It is a fitting testament to the creation of this church and the worldwide outreach of Loyola. Like a smaller Vatican in so many ways. ...

SPECTACULAR. ABSOLUTELY BREATHTAKING! Rivals what you will see at the Vatican without the lines & free. Although I still recommend going to see the Vatican Museums!) Walking distance from the Pantheon.

A Beautiful Church in a City of Churches. As our son teaches at a Jesuit School we decided to add this church to our itinerary. It was worth the visit for the colourful ceilings and quiet atmosphere. This church was built in the 17th century so by Roman standards it is new. While the ceilings are ornate they are fresh and modern and lack the decadence of some of the other churches. Entrance as in most churches is free and it is located close to the Pantheon so take a minute when passing to look inside.

Beautiful. Having gone to St Ignatius Primary School, Sunbury, UK, I was intrigued to visit the Roman equivalent - I say that in the loosest of terms, the Roman church is amazing with beautiful decor and architecture. Some of the churches here beat visiting the Vatican Museum hands down (especially if you have young children).
Went to Rome with a Jesuit. This was not on the itinerary but our chaplain was a Jesuit so we made a visit. Beautiful art. Another gorgeous Church.

If you only visit one other church in Rome.... ..... make it this one.Interesting history and special interior. Read about the dome and then enjoy the visual trick being played on visitors by the 17c builders.

Peaceful and Amazing. The history of the perceived cupola is inspiring, the innovation is copied in many other churches we saw, but none are as dramatic. The surrounding altars are wonderful, each unique and calming and the wood and plastic sculpture pictured above was quite amazing and combined the old with the current geography of the world today.

Dome & Fresco- Wonders to be enjoyed at peace!. Here is a wonderful church that contains a perceptive illusion dome which is a trick to the eyes & a massive fantastic fresco which can be enjoyed at peace. Stand at the marked place to see the dome, take few steps further to see it painted clearly on a flat ceiling- simply stunning.The fresco is marvellous- A ray of light from the Holy Father to St. Ignatius which he spreads to the 4 continents depicted in allegorical representations, Horse for Europe, Camel for Asia, Jaguar for America & Crocodile for Africa. When you stand in the centre & look up, it feels like you are looking into the sky!!All this you can enjoy peacefully- hence a visit to Sant' Ignatius of Loyolo Church is a must!!
amazing place. it is like every & each place in Rome. full of history. you breath history all the time. this church is a bit different. it got it's own feeling.

Fool the Eye. You come here to see the masterpiece of trompe l'oeil (fool the eye) painting on the ceiling. It LOOKS like a beautifully decorated dome, but it's actually flat. Look at it while standing on each of the two brass plates on the floor. From one it looks fantastic, and you will swear it is actually a dome. From the other you can see clearly how "messed up" it is revealing the truth. This isn't the only example in Rome, either. We spent quite a bit of time looking at some of these things, trying to decide "paint or plaster." There are lots of huge paintings and statues here; we were struck by the giant carved spiraling "Jade" columns on the main altar. The rest of the church is quite glorious.

Fabulous - Do not miss visiting. What a magnificent church with its chapels and paintings. The wood/plastic model of the "world church" is amazing and took 28 years to construct. Unfortunately some of the model churches have been stolen. The major cities in the various countries of the world, together with their populations, are inscribed on the model.This beautiful church warranted a second visit during our stay in Rome. No toilet facilities are available in the church.

See frescoes in the right setting - unlike the Sistine Chapel crush!. Of course like everyone we saw the Sistine chapel ceiling and yes, it is beautiful and amazing, but really trying to look at it properly surrounded by 5000 other people all in the same room... You don't really get it. If you too were disappointed by the crowds, try this lovely church near the Pantheon. Free to enter, in lower season at least it's quiet inside, cool and tranquil. You can sit as long as your neck can stand staring up at the ceiling, wondering and the spectacular perspective effects of the paintings, as well as the false dome painting. Here you get the space and time to look carefully, in more peaceful surroundings that befit a church. Do drop in here if you visit the Pantheon.
Just up the street from the Pantheon. Stumbled upon this after visiting the Pantheon. One day f the most beautiful churches in all of Roma. Please visit

Worth A Pop In Visit. The church is near the Pantheon and it's FREE. It is worth a quick stroll through. The interesting nugget for me was the middle dome ceiling. As you walk in it appears to be a regular dome, however it is actually a flat surface painted as if it were a dome. It's a funny little optical illusion that isn't expected.

A hidden masterpiece. This is truly an amazing masterpiece. We stumbled on this church by chance on our way from Campo de Fiori to Pantheon. The ceiling is amazing...a true work of art. This is a church you MUST visit whilst in Rome.

The 'Fake Dome'. This church is known to many for its 'fake dome'. Because of lack of fund during construction, they were unable to afford a dome, so the artist actually 'drew' a dome. The ceiling is in fact flat, but looks as if there is a dome. Very deceiving and interesting. There's a yellow spot on the floor, which is said to be the best place to look up and enjoy this tricky mastermind creation. Besides, the paintings on the ceiling are amazing, especially when the sunshine plays on them. It's not as crowded as Pantheon or Navona, so we were able to sit and watched for quite a while.
Wonderful church. This church is different from the other churches in Rome as it is known for its 3D ceiling.. Also known in English as the church of St Ignatius of Loyola.

The beauty is in the 'dome'. Worth seeing for a few minutes, if only to admire the genius illusion of the painted dome ceiling in the middle of the church. Apparently they ran out of money to install a dome, but it isn't noticeable as the artist painted such a wonderful illusion. Make sure to get a view of it from near the altar and see how different the image looks.

Beautiful ceiling. . You can get to the stage in Rome that one church starts to look very much like another but this is one you will remember. The ceiling is stunning and gives the Sistine Chapel a run for it's money. Lots to see and enjoy.
fantastic ceiling. The ceiling alone in the Sistine chapel is worth the visit its absolutely amazing incredibly detailed
The ceiling is amazing!. Lovely church just off Via del Corso. The ceiling is really amazing and the church is definitely worth a visit.

Jaw dropping ceiling. You really cant put into words the beauty of this ceiling painting. It seems 3D. The Sistine Chapel ceiling is amazing and historically very significant, but for sheer beauty, this is one of the most beautiful works of art i have ever seen. Masterful use of perspective. Do not miss this gem only a couple minutes walk from the Pantheon.

Not to be missed!!!. If you are walking the city, this Basilica is not to be missed. Please note prior to walking into the church that the outside roof is flat; inside, you can't believe the domed ceilings. This basilica is quite beautiful and an amazing piece of architecture.
Nice Church.. The architecture is amazing! The building on the outside looks amazing and the art work inside is so delicate and detailed.

Not just another church. There are so many churches in Rome that it becomes a blur after a while but this one is worth seeking out for its trompe l'oiel 'dome' ceiling and its barrel vault baroque illusion.

Wonderful fresco. The Church of Sant'Ignazio doesn't look much from the outside but inside is a delight. The ceiling fresco is a staggeringly beautiful work of art, and for me, much better than the Cistine Chapel. The other real delight is a wooden model of a multi-denominational church featuring 30-40 entrances modelled on different religious buildings from all around the world - a delightful concept and a pity it was "just" a scale model.
wow.. We just stumbled across this church and so glad we did the ceiling, frescos and sculptures are amazing. Visit this church if you get the chance.
Lovely church. Beautiful church. Not crowded. The fabulous wooden construction pictured above is amazing. There is no admission fee and it is well worth the visit.

One of the most beautiful churches in Rome. We just happened to stumble upon this church. It's took my breath away. I couldn't believe the statues and artwork that was hidden inside this church. Beautiful.

If you like Lapis Lazuli, dont miss this. spectacular church. Ignatius Loyola was buried in style. THough I always feel sorry for the labourers who were probably exploited, they could at least look back on their creation with real pride
Gorgeous and Uncrowded. We visited primarily because of Trip Advisor ratings. Go. You won't regret it. Only a five minute walk from the Pantheon. Pictures say more than words.

Must see (you'll probably walk past it). On the way to Trevi or Pantheon, take 15 minutes to experience the opulence of a 17th century church which contains the tomb of St Ignatius of Loyola.Check out the official website santignazio.gesuiti.it. The main feature of the church is the great vault fresco made by Andrea Pozzo which took 3 years to complete (refer photo).Enjoy this break from Rome hustle.
Not Just Another Church in Rome. Don't walk by this beauty without stepping inside. It's exterior is non-descript yet its interior is a work of art. Simply beautiful and worth the visit.

Incredible!. The paintings on the ceiling of this beautiful church make use of the architectural elements, which make the figures above you come to life in a three-dimensional like way. Simply amazing and beautiful. The funding for the project ran out and the church had to get creative about how to finish the last dome -- it's pretty cool how they resolved the issue but it is totally worth a visit to see.

Well worth it on your way to or from the Pantheon. The incredible painted ceiling is the glory of this church.We liked the peace of the place and the provision of recorded sacred music which added to the atmosphere.

A Must See. This marvelous church is a short distance from the Pantheon. From the street, the Sant'Ignazio Church is unassuming. Once inside, it is breath-taking. The three dimensional ceiling paintings are awe-inspiring works of art regardless of your religious predilections. This is what Renaissance art is all about. Of all the sights, we visited in Rome, this is among the most memorable.

Magnificent Fresco in the ceiling. While doing the Centro Storico walk, we visited the circular Church of St. Ignatius de Loyola. In this church, the fresco in the ceiling differentiates it from others. The colorful fresco depicting St. Ignatius and his works which were done by Andrea Pozzo dominated the entire church.

Church is Beautiful, A Must See. Found this church while walking in the area. The church is amazing and so much to admirer. I was amazed at the Temple of Christ The King display (1:200 scale) that Vincenzo Pandolfi started making at age 70 and finished it at age 98 shortly before dying. Definitely worth stopping at while in Rome.

A hint of Heaven complete with music. The church of Saint Ignatius of Loyola is one of the Jesuit churches in Rome that was built to inspire fervor in those who questioned the Catholic faith after the Counter-Reformation. The artworks throughout the church do just that. The music that plays as you walk around add to the entire experience. For me, seeing the altar of Robert Bellarmine was a pleasant surprise, since he is a favorite saint of my associate pastor. The experience was just beyond expectation.

YOU MUST VISIT!. OK...this was probably the most awe-inspiring church for me! You can actually almost walk past it, rather discreet, as most of the churches are from the street. We literally walked in and I just exploded in goose bumps! My husband just whispered...WOW! The ceiling, in my opinion, is much more beautiful than even the Sistine Chapel. This is a MUST SEE

A Rare Jewel.. This church of St. Ignatius of Loyola was something we stumbled upon on our way to the Pantheon. I must say that this was by far one of the nicest churches I've come across, something that was on par with St. Peter's in my opinion. The artwork on the dome and magnificent craftsmanship is something to be admired.

Amazing church in an amazing piazza. The church boast one of the biggest fresco ceiling in the world, to admire it you have to stand on the yellow circular spots on the floor, look above and give some time to embrace the three dimensional illusion. Another highlight is the dome: as they run out of money they changed the original project and now the dome is painted. Another example of perfect control of perspective.

Beautiful surprise during our walk. We found this while walking around Rome. It was a perfect little gem. We had our three joys and they were impressed too. The ceiling mural was very impressive. My husband went to a Jesuit school so he was thrilled to have found this b

Superb! A must see. It's free!. We did a walking tour in Milan and the guide told us to make SURE we visit this church when we get to Rome. The famous painted dome as they ran out of money. rhe sweet spot is if you stand on a marble circle that has been placed in the floor. The ambience in this church was amazing as their was beautiful music playing.

Spectacular . Once inside it make you feel tiny, which is probably what the builders wanted to. It is very beautiful inside, a lot of workmanship had gone into it. The fresca on the ceiling is a thing of beauty

It takes your breath away. We had been to the Pantheon and walking down a side street we came to the church my husband and I went in not knowing what we would see . What we saw was out of this world the amazing paintings, but most of all was how very peaceful the church was . We had been in a few churches / Basilicas but this we thought was the best.

Suprisingly lovely. This church looks very pedestrain on the outside. It would be very easy to walk by it without bothering to go in. But go in! Gorgeous painted ceilings. A real stunning church. And it's free.

Fabulous beautiful church. Enjoyed visiting this church after seeing other more touristy areas. This place is a little quieter and good for reflecting. Similar to the church of San Luigi dei francesi which is also beautiful. It's also near the pantheon and the piazza novana so you can see all these without walking too much! would recommend to anyone who likes to look at pieces of art.
Awesome Church. Very Beautiful. Amazing paintings. Very peaceful and place good to recover from your walks. A must see Church.

Enjoyed the paintings. We visited this church as a family of 4 with two teenagers, and all of us were impressed by the paintings in this church, mainly the ones on the ceiling. It has two we especially liked - a false two-dimensional dome, which looks 3-D until you walk around underneath it, and a huge mural of St. Ignatius spreading the gospel to all the corners of the earth. The latter was full of detail, and we enjoyed picking out the representatives of the different areas, including Asia, Africa, Europe, and America. We enjoyed stopping in the church for about 20 minutes, appreciating the cool interior (it was a warm day) and admiring the paintings and their details.
Unfinished completeness. Don't miss the marvel of optical illusion. Look up and go out feeling high. An unfinished but accomplished magic masterpiece.

Beautiful place not to be missed.. We came across this church by accident really on our way to another attraction. We had already visited St. Peter's, which is amazing. This church is just as amazing in a smaller way. We were so pleased not to have missed it. A truly beautiful place with stunning chapels within, pictures of the place just don't do it justice.

Very gold and glitzy. Another free and beautiful church. Lots of gold and marble.
The wood plastic model for world peace is fantastic.
Worth going into. I know there's just so many and one cannot go into all of them and after a few, you start to get all churched out but this is worth visiting.
Worth the visit. Amazing architecture, for a church that is actually not of the most famous ones. What I liked the most was the absence of tourists at 9 am. Stunning and worth the visit.
Beautiful church . One of the most beautiful churches in Rome! The architecture, very much like many other buildings in Rome, shows the Roman Catholic pomp but creates a great atmosphere.

Near pantheon . While trying to get to Spanish steps from pantheon , we stopped by this church. There was a guy in the entrance collecting donation. I'm unsure whether he is affiliated with the church. I did not have cash so I did not give money.  The ceilings of the church is masterfully painted tromp de toile style . The sculptures were very impressive ... Almost showing movement.

Beautiful church. We happened upon this church (as it happens in Rome!) and we stopped in for a short visit. We had just been to the Vatican and it was amazing how the ceiling here is also beautifully decorated with frescoes. It was quite quiet and impressive. Worth stopping in!
Add to Your Church Visits. Very similar to the Vatican - with very elaborate paintings and gold-accented walls-to-ceiling art. Can't miss this if you're in the Trevi Fountain area.

Amazing Church.....and just have to be visited.. Churches are all over Rome, but after so many visits to the city, I happened to decide and enter this Church for the first time, as it was on my way back from the Pantheon and Piazza Navona, and I was gladly surprised and amazed at the work, the ceiling, the treasure I uncovered,....the painted ceiling is among the most beautiful I have seen, make a point to visit it.
One of the best churches in Rome!. Amazing ceiling!! Just go, it's absolutely a must, you will not be disappointed! One of the best churches in Rome!!
Jaw-dropping!. I, who wasn't that impressed by the Sixtine Chapel, was speechless in the Church of Sant'Ignazio di Loyola... Both the ceiling and the artefacts are to be seen.

Beautiful . I think it's one of the most beautiful churches I've ever visited! People should have respect while visiting and cover their shoulders and knees. Pay attention to the paintings on the ceiling, they look tridimentional

Stunning Ceiling !. Sant' Ignazio di Loyola is a hidden away, unassuming edifice that houses the most stunning painted ceiling in in Rome.
The remainder of the church is very worthy of a visit, but the ceiling is its stand-out 'blow you away' factor. The trompe l'oeil effects will have you wondering what's 2D and 3D.
Wander in, it's worth it !

Spectacular Church . Just stumbled across this church & from the outside we weren't expecting anything special.
However when we walked in we were pleasantly suprised by the astonishing decoration inside, with a special mention to the 'Painted Dome', which had to be used instead of an actual dome die to the church running out of money!
Must see when in Rome!
Chiesa del Gesú' sister Church. This a temple dedicated to Sant' Ignazio di Loyola, you will be surprised with the ceiling's frescoes!

Most impressive church in Rome. By far the most spectacular ceiling of any church in Rome. The fake dome is absolutely incredible, and the main mural stunning, breathtaking... AMAZING! I cannot encourage you enough to visit this stunning place.

Stumbled on a Gem!. We wandered in here to get out of the heat of a walking tour and it was amazing to see. You could gaze at the "painted" dome forever -they couldn't build a dome as they ran out of funding! Not too far from the Spanish Steps and the Trevi Fountain.

All in One Church. If for nothing else, go to just see the All in One Church piece that is located in this place. The ceiling is pretty awesome as well if the All in One Church art does not satisfy your need for art.

Wandered in here on my first day, went back again. Accidentally wandered in here while on my way to the pantheon from the spanish steps on my first day... Wow was I glad I did. I could sit in the church for days dazing at the magnificent mural on the ceiling or the beautiful sculptures. Must see. The dome is so convincingly round!
Incredible Art. Incredibly beautiful. My girlfriend stumbled into this treasure and we were literally mesmerized. Definitely worth a look.
Breathtaking/Impressive. I didn't expect this cathedral to be at impressive, but it definitely was worth visiting. We visited it on the way to the Pantheon, and I must say it was breathtaking.
Beautiful church. This is an amazing and beautiful church. You will need to cover your shoulders, no shorts above the knees.
Wow wow just wow. We could spend hours inside !'the architecture , colours , style , just breath taking moment ,we recommend to visit this basilica .
part of the second level tourist spots in rome. of the many churches in rome this is a very nice one to see the ceiling artwork. its not the sistine chapel, but would try to fit it in if time
Surprise!!!. What a surprise!! We stepped in an open doorway and walked into a treasure! Beautiful paintings, statues and the wood carving of churches around the world should be in a museum!

Beautiful church inside. Had been thinking of visiting this church since my father and stepdaughter both went to Loyola University in Maryland, and without asking, our tour guide took us to see it. It was beautiful inside. Worth seeing.
churches. Church of Ignatius Loyola founder of the Jesuits. Unique and very interesting very different from most of Rome's churches
Enjoy. i so loved this church! i would suggesr that you find the secret of the dome as it will be quite a surprise. The church is in centro historico and well worth looking for . Enjoy!

WOW. THE BEST CHURCH IF ALL. We stumbled across this church while wandering around. It beats the Sistine chapel which we saw a few days later. Hardly anyone around. Sunday 1030 such a wonderful monument. Amazing can't recommend highly enough to see this place. Very unassuming on the outside.

Do NOT miss out on this stunning church!. Little known - I didn't even have it on my list of to-see's until Reese Witherspoon spoke of it on her Instagram. Nothing special on the outside, but walk inside and you will be in awe. Simply amazing.

Another Beautiful 17th Century Church. This was one of the churches that was not closed to the public between noon and 3pm. This 17th century church houses many impressive frescoes, sculptures and paintings. This church may be best known for its “painted dome”, which isn’t a dome at all. The church ran out of money and were never able to complete the dome so they had Andrea Pozzo paint a 3D dome on the flat ceiling space were the dome would have been. It is an amazing piece of work.

A little known Rome highlight. Easy to miss if you are focusing on the major Rome highlights but close to the Pantheon is this breathtaking church. One of our Rome highlights . Step inside and get blown away. More impressive to me than the Cistine chapel, but that might be down to the 3 hours queue to get to see the Cistine! Do not miss this church - and it's free!
Peaceful. A very beautiful place I like to go with my family, very peaceful and not so many tourist to be quiet.

Simply Stunning..... Although im not a regular visitor to church but this one was an exception for me and trust me it was so so beatifull that i ca say my trip to rome woulldnt have been complete without visiting this church.

Tromp l’oeil worth seeing. This church is worth a look! The imposing order of Corinthian pilasters that rings the entire interior, the theatrical focus on the high altar and the bold Tromp l’oeil paintings in the "dome" at its crossing and in the nave ceiling, all produce a sumptuous effect. The dome was never completed due to the church running out of money, so they hired a painter to depict the dome. My father who travelled with me, kept saying "look at the fabulous light from the ceiling!" where there actually was no light, just paintings. It is wonderful!

Stunning. One of our favorite churches in Rome. We recommend to visit in the evening to have a good chance to catch a concert - it's a magic all together: the architecture, the acoustics, the lights... Very deep and unique atmosphere.

Look up!. As another reviewer has commented, this is close to the Pantheon and is well worth a small diversion. It has two great features. Firstly there is the wooden model of a the worldwide church. Secondly,as I have entitled this review, look up. There is the perspective painting covering where the cupola would have been and then there is the painting over the nave. I found this to be more impressive than the much more famous ceiling of the Sistine Chapel with the added advantage of no crowds and freedom to take photgraphs.

My favorite church in all of Rome. My sons study at a Jesuit school in Texas, so I was looking forward to visiting this church, and it was beyond my expectations. It is beautiful! The ceiling murals and all of the interior of this church is spectacular. We had a guide who explained it all to us, so we were fortunate to have that expertise while we visited. The tourists visiting the church were quiet and respectful which made the visit very pleasant and peaceful. If you are catholic, and especially if you are familiar with the Jesuits, it's a must see.

Definitely worth a look. This church is really quite cool. There is a “dome” in the middle that is really just a painted on, flat dome. They ran out of money when they were building it, so they got someone to paint the illusion of the dome. Looking at it from different places inside the church gives you a 2D vs 3D vision of the “dome.”

Surprisingly beautiful. Nice stop after visiting Pantheon and other Jesuit church, Gesu. Since I went to Jesuit college in the US, this was a must and didn't disappoint. The frescos telling the story of St. Ignatius of Loyola were amazing and the wooden church display (pictured above) was impressive. Doesn't take long to pop in and see it all, but be sure to spend most of your time looking at the ceiling.

Heavily baroque. St. Ignatius is buried here; he's the founder of the Jesuit order of priests, called the Society of Jesus. This church is not dazzling like other Roman churches but heavily ornate--purposefully so in the baroque gilded style.
Extraordinary. The mastery of the artist who painted the ceiling, and the "dome" is simply extraordinary. This is certainly worth a peek if you are in the area of the Pantheon or the Piazza Navona.

Lavish with lots of treats!. Stumbled across this little jewel wandering around. Lavishly decorated. Great ceiling fresco emphasizing architectural perspective! There is no center dome but instead a round black canvas painted tromp l'oeil to resemble one! Also, do not miss the Ludovisi tomb to the right of the altar. Notice the way the marble is done to look like flowing draperies!

Relax, pray and stop for a while!. One of the most beautiful churches in Rome... the roof is just extraordinary... up there with the greats! Its also a wonderful place to reflect, pray, and slow down from the hectic pace of travel and sight seeing. Also, if you are here on a Sunday, just down the road toward the Corso, is a beautiful little Chapel called Carravita... its where Mozart played music when he was in Rome... at 11AM there is an English Mass... another joy of Rome.

Sant Ignazio. Heavenly ceiling.. This church is probably more walked past than entered,being close to the spectacular Pantheon,it can be inadvertently missed on the way to The Trevi Fountain. With your back to the entrance of The Pantheon,taking a 90deg right turn and a 200m walk will have you adjacent to the church door. The interior is quite awesome.The ceiling,by Andrea Pozzo (c.1685),is up there with the finest frescoes in Rome (and I've seen most of them). The sheer size of the place is also a surprise,given its relatively inauspicious exterior (although that is quite common with most of the City's churches). An added bonus to a visit here is a magnificent large wooden model of a church,on display near the main door,which on closer inspection consists of many smaller ones in a circular configuration around the larger one.In conclusion,your time here will be well spent.

Stunning. To say this church is stunning is an understatement. I was lucky walking past it one evening when they had a free concert. The entire experience was just beautiful!! Next time I am in Rome, I will definitely re-visit!

Wonderful church to visit. I wouldn't miss this church if you're in the area. It's lovely inside and has a few things that are quite unique among all the various amazing churches in Rome. It stood out as being one of my favorites. My young children liked it a lot as well and they were tired of looking at churches by this point in our trip.
Baroque and beautiful. Hard to imagine a better example of baroque art and architecture. Fabulous painting and decoration. Pause to really take in the ceiling and the "fake dome."

HIDDEN GEM UNDERSTATES . Hard to find and not marked on many maps this gem is a block from Pizza Navona and similar distance from Pantheon. Beautifully proportioned and unlike most still with active congregation. Ceilings are more interesting than Sistine Chapel & not as high.Gregorian hymns were flowing thru the church when we were there adding to the feeling. Pretty piazza in front.Take the time to visit the church of the founder of the Jesuits if in the area.
Illusions inside. Exactly as written in the guide books. The paintings, especially the one on the ceiling was breath-taking.

A hidden gem. this church is a few minute walk from the Pantheon, and a must see on the way to the Trevi fountain. The paintings and side chapels are spectacular. It is off the usual Rome trail, but definitely worth spending time to admire the tribute to St. Ignatious.

Over the top / stunning. The ceiling rivals the Sistine Chapel for scale and brilliance of execution. It wins out by being a bit less visited and so easier to view as well as being in a relatively quiet section of Rome.

Where you find Pozzo's masterful dome and ceiling fresco. Church of Sant'Ignazio di Loyola (free entry) is a lovely church to visit in Rome, most famous for its works by Jesuit brother Andrea Pozzo. Originally consecrated in 1722, this is a Baroque style building dedicated to the founder of the Jesuits Society, Ignatius of Loyola. Opening hours are 7am to 7pm daily. Here you can find plenty of ornate altarpieces, heavy gilding, stucco figures, marble pillars and other elements of Baroque and Rocco architecture. However, it is the works of Andrea Pozzo that excite us when it comes to visiting Sant'Ignazio di Loyola. To start with, the ceiling fresco called Trompe l'ceil of Sant'Ignazio is remarkable. Perhaps no other peer in Rome offers a richer 3 dimensional perspective, with angelic figures seeming to extend into an open sky and heavens with buildings towering above. It is a dazzling display of Pozzo's skill that is rarely matched and a real treat to look at and admire. As you walk a bit further into the nave, you soon encounter another of Pozzo's fantastic paintings, the illusionary dome fresco. From the centre position you can't help but think you are looking upward into an inner dome. Only after walking to the side and up close do you realise that you are simply looking at an illusionary style painting that has tricked your eyes, just as Pozzo had intended. This is a fun masterpiece to find and one you will long remember seeing after returning home from Rome. Do spend a bit time looking over the altar and the beautiful apse ceiling fresco as well. It is another gorgeous work by Pozzo. The rest of the church is quite impressive as well. However, it will be the works of Pozzo that you will long remember of your visit here.Note: There are many very good attractions in this area of Rome. You can easily combine a visit to Sant'Ignazio di Loyola with the likes of the Pantheon, Santa Maria sopra Minerva, Galleria Doria Pamphilj and others.

Striking. The church has fantastic paints and images. It is necessary to dedicate some hours to view details of these impressive works.
magnificient. incredible details of sculptures and paintings. a great master work . Must to see it. The dimensions of this church are amazing. it is different from the point of view of details.

Not another Church? Very definitely not! This is The Church not to miss.. Strolling to get the bus back to the hotel and we were drawn to this, and what a find. This seemed to be on the scale of St Peter's, so much so that there is the plaster model displayed of one of the statues produced in marble for St Peters.Much has been eloquently written about this and it's attractions, suffice to say that in my opinion, add this to your MUST VISIT List

A wonderful peaceful experience. As the mother church of the Society of Jesus I have wanted to visit this for a while. The Tromp l'oeil by Andrea Pozzo SJ is something you have to experience first hand. Nothing I think can capture th efeeling of the effect of moving toward the bronze disk in the floor an watching the ceiling rise up to it 'full height'!!!!. Only thing I would add is that it would have been great to tour some of the hall ways leading to the Jesuit offices that Pozzo also painted.The side chapels are really interesting particularly the one to St Aloysius Gonzaga. Learning more about his family history and their importance in Europe has been great.Had the pleasure of attending the 2013 Christmas midnight mass there. While not understanding any of the Italian it was a wonderful experience.Actual visit December 2013

Fantastic frescoes well worth finding when in Roma. our guide when visiting the Vatican told us that some of the best frescoes in all of Italy were in this church and yes they were stunning! Very impressive, it's a bit off the hidden but very near the Pantheon, well worth searching for and well especially worth going to see if you visit the pantheon.

Amazing..just open the door!. We were strolling along and saw yet another church. We opened the doors and were gobsmacked with the absolute treasure trove of statues and alters inside this church. A must see. Totally unexpected as we had never heard of this church before.
Don't miss this Church. Don't miss this church. Stay under the "dome" and experience the illusion. Free guided tour is offered. the ceiling is magnificent. And they have a Saturday vigil mass.

Beautiful!!!!. One of the churches my wife and I had planned to see on our trip, the Church of Sant'Ignazio di Loyola did not disappoint. The church itself is absolutely beautiful, but the major piece to look for here is the trompe l'oeil dome painted by Andrea Pozzo. This was because the church ran out of money to build an actual dome. It is an absolutely spectacular work of deception by Pozzo as it looks as if a real dome awaits from the main entryway of the church down the nave.
Stunning. The ceiling in this church is stunning - 3D +++ Well worth seeking out. Even better for being peaceful.

Hidden Treasure. We had read the reviews about this church on trip advisor and it was even better!! What a beautiful church - up there with the best. Definitely find some time to visit and admire the art work - it really is beautiful. Tucked away near the Pantheon, it's worth he time!!!

Happy accident. We wandered in on a whim and it was magnificent. So beautiful, and music playing, and so many people praying. Still decorated for Christmas when we were there, so we got to see the AMAZING nativity scene, complete with lights and running water.

Gorgeous with Beautiful 3D frescoes. The plain exterior hides a gorgeous Baroque interior with impressive 3D frescoes. Even a "false dome". Close to Pantheon but on a quiet street. Go while the sun is shining to get the best view of the paintings. Free. Photos and quiet talking are allowed. During services portions of church are off limits. We liked it better than St Peters. Something extra special in a city filled with special.

A Big Surprise. When i arrived in front of the church, I felt like I should not expect much because it looks just like a normal church. Once I got in, my expectation was blown away because the paintings inside are so fantastic. The 3-D paintings are very well created. I have never seen something like this before.In summary, this place is a MUST-GO attraction, especially, it is not far from the other main attractions.
Hidden treasure. The most beautiful church I have every visited, completely stunned, worth a visit, or two, or three...

Church of St Ignacius. This really is a huge church, but it still manages to have a homey feel to it. ( Like all the Jesuit Churches) The ceiling is very impressive and they are kind enough to have a mirror so that you wont have to strain your neck looking at it. Pay particular attention to the optical illusion !!

A special church and worth visiting and returning. While one could literally visit hundreds of churches in Rome, this one is among the very special. Beautiful architecture and artifacts. You will love the beauty and history.

Just gorgeous!. We did not plan to visit it, but decided to go in while on the way somewhere else. Totally worthy! It is an amazingly gorgeous church, with very rich ornaments. Not crowded, so you can stay as long as you want and admire it carefully. No fee admission. Of course if you only have a day in Rome you'd skip it, but if you have free time or you just happen to be nearby, do go in at least for a couple of minutes.

A hidden Gem. Was introduced to this church on an evening tour. I was not aware that it existed. We were so impressed that we came back the next day to give it more time. The deceptive painting of the ceiling and the "dome" interior is fascinating. An added bonus was the organist practicing. A free organ recital to boot.

could seem nicer than sistine chapel. father pozzo did a unique jolb in creating a 3 dimensional ceiling in this church. no stress, no lines, no admittance fee and you can spend all the time u want enjoying it
One of the many churces to see in Rome. After St. Peters, and St. John Lateran, everything else just fades a little.St. Ingatious' tomb is there, and very pretty.
A must see. You won't be disappointed by visiting this church. The ceiling is simply amazing. Right next to the Pantheon so easily found.

Beautiful ceiling. Pozzo's masterpiece. Absolutely stunning visually, and messes with your mind a bit. Unfortunately some idiot released a balloon that went up to the ceiling and sat there, but what can you do. Free to enter and wasn't that crowded, certaintly compared to the Panthon next door.
Awesome Paintings a must visit place in Rome. We went there twice just to look at the painting on the ceiling. A must go to place in my humble opinion.

Stunningly beautiful - you must visit. I'd read about this church when looking up interesting places to visit in Rome and read several reviews describing how beautiful it is. How very true - it is absolutely stunning. You could spend hours there looking at the beautiful art work and we visited this church 3 times while in Rome. It is just a few minutes walk from the Pantheon (also truly amazing) so well worth taking a detour. I'd done the whole vatican tour thing on my first day in Rome and was excited to finally get to see the Cistine Chapel. I'm going to sound like a complete philistine now but I was somewhat disappointed by it. After the almost 3 hour vatican tour and the guides constant references and build up I was slightly let down. I genuinely think the Church of Sant'Ignazio is more beautiful.
A Dome in perspective. great tribute to the Jesuit background. tremendous "Dome" painted in perspective. The altar and side chapels are also superb.

Beautiful artwork all around. This church is mostly out of any popular itinerary schedules and tourist path but this place truly deserves to be on a priority list. Rome is not devoid of beautiful churches but then again this one has a unique character of its own. It is also one of the oldest known Jesuit churches. The artworks inside are breathtaking. There are not much crowd around here which makes it pretty convenient in exploring the place.
Serene and awesome. I have walked by it for years and finally decided to explore Its church alters, statuary and religious artifacts are above beautiful.

Beautiful Church worth a Visit. Visited this church immediately after the Pantheon (a hard act to follow). I've always been a fan of the Jesuit churches and this one did not disappoint. Beautiful ceiling frescos, ornate side chapels, beautiful columns and floors, and I got a kick out of the fake painted dome. Free and uncrowded too.

UNBELIEVABLE. We LOVED it, it's HUGE and really beautiful. Our favorite part was, when you first walk in, there's a model of a ficticious church - "Temple of Christ the King - Ut Unum Sint". We loved it. St Robert Bellarmine is buried here!
Church. Holy. Visit the Adoration chapel. Pray by relic of St Francis Xavier. Experience the Holy Name of Jesus. IHS.
Large beautiful church - remember to look up. Ugh - after a long day of sightseeing - we went here last and forgot to look up! Oh, well, it was a big beautiful church even without looking up.
Nice church to pop in. Nice church to pop in from the street. No lines, no tickets, great difference between outside world and inside.

Worth going. It's a very special church, but with little information and not in most guides! But it's a must go!
The afrescos on top are beautiful.

Best place in Rome. We went to many Churches in Rome and spent a couple days at Vatican City. I would put this on any list of top 3 places to see. If you only had a couple hours in Rome, this is the place you should go.
A must-see !. The only chuch in Rome that used paint to pretend to have a dome... A must-see as it is really well done :)
Amazing Church with amazing missionary history. A must visit in Rome - the amazing second Jesuit church in the world. From the Jesuits that brought us the best pope ever - Pope Francis.

Must see!. This was not originally on our list of place to visit, but I am very glad we found this beautiful church. It is huge inside, and the artwork on the ceiling is especially amazing. After several days visiting cathedrals and churches in Rome and the Vatican, I did not think I could still be impressed by another church, but I was wrong! The ornate column, alters and artwork are incredible. It was also not very crowded, which also lead to the feeling of awe being in such a beautiful huge church.

amazing. Make sure you do not injure your neck as you look at the ceilings to see the incredible Baroque paintings. Foreshortening, false and deep perspectives, trompe l'oeil and other optic tricks are all used. Then there are the sculptures and bas-reliefs throughout the church, each a treasure in their own rights. This is the mother ship of all Jesuit churches so it is rich in history as well. Not to be missed.

Beats the Sistine ceiling. We just happened to stop briefly going from one crowded tourist attraction to another. Why this cathedral isn't at the top of attractions is a mystery? By far more beautiful than the Vatican which we viewed hours earlier. the ceiling is stunning and so interesting with the fake dome fresco. The sculptures were massive and colorful incorporating many different stones and marbles. No lines, no crowds and no tickets. Hint: pay the .50€ to turn the lights on the dome. The meter is next to the model on the right side halfway down the center of the main hall.

Just wandered in, glad I did. This is well worth a look in the door. The paintings are wonderful and the organ sounded great. It is not St Peter's Basillica but it is beautiful. You could easily walk past so keep an eye out for it.

Magical. Magical church magnificent sceneri!my guide was suggesting that i should visit other ones but one day i passed by and i thought just to go in by curiosity.and it was so beautiful i changed my mind about skipping the church visits!

Inspiring ceiling. I wasn't aware of this church before visiting Rome, but because short on time, we decided to skip the Vatican and the Sistine Chapel (I know, I know, but no great loss to me). My mother, however, did have this on her list of top sights to see in Rome, surprisingly. Aside from the Colosseum for highlights of my trip, the ceiling frescoes were a stunner to view in person. It's also less frequented than, say, the Pantheon, which is a few minutes' walk to here. It's a must-see, and there's no excuse since it's local to so many other sights.
A beauty!. Space. Lots of space. Well lit altars. Really good to walk around in when the rain pours outside. Dont miss the altar for Santa Rosa de Lima
amazing ceiling. the ceiling is simply extraordinary due to the effect of perspective in frescoes. The church can be considered one of the best examples of Barocco in Italy.

A very nice surprise. We entered this church by chance as it was not on our list of must visit placed and I have to say we were really impressed. Starting with the very interesting " Church of the world" piece imnediately after you enter on the right side, continuing with the great paintings on the ceiling which are really beautiful and finishing with the fake dome (it is 3D paintined, it is not a real dome). The experience is awesome and the best thing is the fact that this church is not crowded. Excellent!!!
Must see. Hidden away off the main street, this church boasts a ceiling that has an intricate theology behind it. Definitely a must see.
unique. this place is one of a kind. it may look like a "simple" baroque church, but wait until you go inside and look at the cupola!
unbelievable. what a magnificent place! you cannot miss this place. check out the dome....genius!!!!!!!!!!!! definitely recommended
Beautiful. The 'dome' cieling painting is amazing!!! A hidden church between the Pantheon and Piazza Navona - a definite place to see!

Unexpected surprise. This church was a 2 minute walk behind our hotel. The artwork in this church is amazing. The church doesn't have a dome but you could not tell that from looking at the art hanging from the ceiling. It appears as if you are looking at a painted dome. This church does not get the traffic that a lot of the churches in Rome get. I was there all alone except for a janitor on a Tuesday morning around 9. Also if you are Catholic they have a daily Mass at 8 AM which we attended several times during our stay.They also have an English speaking tour for free. Very nice.
Worth finding!. Missed out on this gem the first time we visited Rome, well worth the detour, it's only a couple of minutes from Pantheon. You won't be disappointed!

A hidden gem!!. A magnificient church, "hidden" near the roman Pantheon, with free entrance and not usually packed with people. It has a wonderful interior, beautifully decorated, and an amazing trompe l'œil ceiling by Andrea Pozzo that seems to have curved edges. From a mark on the floor you can best experience this illusion and see the "dome", which doesn't really exist - it is nothing but a large round canvas with the perspective picture of the dome that was supposed to be built there.
Special story. Just on the way to piazza navona we happend to bump into this beautiful church. The ceiling is the story of this magnificent place!

THE CEILING!!!. I did not visit this church on my first visit to Rome, but was taken there by our tour guide this time. It is absolutely amazing! Smaller than, but rivals, the Sistine Chapel, and you are allowed to take pictures. You must go!
Wonderful Baroque church. Make time to view this church. It was not packed with people, it was beautiful, it has painted dome ceilings, and it's free!

All about the Ceiling. I'm not sure this deserves to be at the top of the list in Rome, but it's definitely worth visiting to see the ceiling. The ceiling is massive, taking up the whole nave (I think I got that nomenclature right). It's painted in such a way as to give the illusion of extending the architecture up into heaven through an open ceiling. To properly view the ceiling, look for a large dot built into the floor. It's painted from that perspective, so it works best from that angle. If you look at it from the back, it won't seem nearly as impressive. It's impossible to give the illusion from every vantage point. You'll know you're at the right place, because the false painted dome looks believable from there too. Take a few pictures. You might actually find that the lower parts of the painted architecture almost fool you when you look back at them.
Worth seeing. It is worth stopping here even if only for a few minutes, to see the ceiling. As it is very close to the Pantheon, it is just a minute or two away.

Nicely tucked away near Pantheon. Beautiful and tricky cieling gives impression of dome when it is flat. A Native American in the painting referring to spread of Christianity. Across the street is the police headquarters for art theft in the yellow buildings. Avoid the cafe around the corner except for toilets and coffee- food was not good.
Worth a visit. The church is in a tourist hotspot but is set in a quiet piazza. Numerous paintings and sculptures. Why do churches always humble people!

Ceilings illustrate Jesuit philosophy. We happened into this church because it was close to where we were staying near the Pantheon. Oh my goodness what an amazing treat. From the false dome to the 3-d ceiling paintings, we couldn't stop looking (It appears that some of the figures are falling off the ceiling). Do take the guided tour, offered by volunteers, Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday, at 3pm. You'll learn some interesting facts about the Jesuit order as reflected in the artwork. St. Ignatius was never in this church, as it was completed in his honor 3 years after his death, but you will understand the wide appeal of his philosophy today.
Hidden Gem. My favorite church in Rome! The illusionistic ceiling by Andrea Pozzo is unbelievable and brilliant,.. And free! Plus there's a Caravaggio hidden in the back corner!

cornerstone of Baroque architecture. Pay attention to the painted ceiling - find a yellow marble dot on the floor 1/3 into the church - this is the best view point; after - check out the ceiling and cupola from the altar side. This will explain a lot about the technique.
Amazing church. The ceiling has wonderful illusions and you must see it when it's lit up ,although you have to pay 0.50 euro for that ! Close to the Pantheon it's worth passing by and entering.

Worth the Walk. Very impressive church in a city of impressive churches. We made the walk to see Sant'Ignazio because of our connection to the Jesuits. Words cannot properly describe all that is to be seen in side. Like many churches in Rome, the outside is relatively mundane.

Unbelieveable. The optical illusion is just stunning. I could have stared at it for hours...
Truly a must see, which is saying something in a city filled with beautiful churches!

See this with the Gesu church. This church is a two minute walk from the Gesu church, which is also dedicated to Saint Ignatious, founder of the Jesuits. Both contain amazing, ornate decoration and works of art. Neither should be missed.
A Must-See In Rome. Spectacular visuals in this church, along with three Caravaggio paintings. You must visit this church. Simply stunning.

The ceiling!. I came for a short visit to this church and the ceiling was just absolutely incredible. I had seen nothing like it before in Rome. It is a must see. The dome is quite odd, fascinating but not as beautiful as the rest of the church, but as I recall there is quite an interesting story behind it.
Beautiful. Surprising optical illusion painted dome on the ceiling. The sense of space in the building is wonderful when you step in from the busy streets. It's lovely.
Lovely Church. Another breathtakingly-beautiful Roman church, peaceful and uncrowded. Lovely pieces of art and statutary.
Look Up!. This is one of the essentials for art lovers.Don't miss this church.The ceiling has amazing perspective.

Don't let the exterior fool you- it's not to be missed.. The exterior of this church is very unassuming, however, once you enter the church you will be awed by the artwork and sculptures, Everywhere you turn there is another amazing piece of art. Definitely worth the visit.
just wow. this church was amazing..the outdoor decoration is really awesome.i think everyone should like it.great place indeed.

Don't let the exterior fool you- it's not to be missed.. Came upon this amazing church as a place to rest. Nothing auspicious about the exterior, so we were shocked at the ornate side altars and trompel'oeil dome. The one altar and Pope's tomb took our breath away- gold, marble and floating angels. This church is a must see.
Did not expect so much. What a place. The interior is breathtaking. One of the churches in Rome that can not be missed. The natural lighting in the interior gives the paintings a special look.

No expense spared....but 'special' nevertheless. Often read about it - didn't visit until our fifth time in Rome.Saw it this time amazing and definitely one to visit and dwell on. Ornate beyond belief, of course, but the trompel'oeil is really out of this world, and there is space to move around in comfort looking at it (unlike another rather more famous still 'chapel' in Rome!). We'll be sure to visit again in future.

Trompe-l'œil. Trompe-l'œil is an art technique and it's difficult to explain shortly. In this church this technique is very visible. Ceiling and dome are actually flat, but it looks like the ceiling was very high and airy, open to the sky, and the dome is like a real dome if You watch it from the right spot. It's amazing, look at the pictures!

Dazzling ceiling!. This is how you can trick your competitors, when you don't have the money to build a dome on top of you church. Just paint one! You have to see it to believe it (but then again, you hardly see it...).
Another great church.. Another great church. Again not much outside but when you go inside, you are simple in awe. One of the top churches to visit in Rome

Lovely Sunday visit. We went to the church on Sunday and found it quite beautiful. We stayed for part of the service which we also enjoyed, though not speaking Italian. After the Vatican sistine chapel and St. Peter's Basilica there, we'd rate it among the top 3 other churches we visited while in Rome.

What else can I say..... Wow. Just Wow! It is a feast for the eyes, from the ceiling to the exquisite statuary. It is easy to get church overload, so if you are trying to cut down, do leave this one in your plans.

Excellent place to visit!. Unassuming outside, amazing interior with beautiful frescos, marble columns, numerous small naves, altars. A must seen when in Rome. Bring your camera! One location not to miss.
beautiful church near the Pantheon. This church his just a few blocks from the Pantheon (a must see for every traveller, even return visitors). The frescos and other decorations are impressive.

Keep your sights high. This has one of the best dome paintings in Rome. There is a gray light box on the right side of the nave so be sure to drop a 50 cent piece in it, so you can see a little of the fool-the-eye painting. Walk around a little until the painted lantern in the dome appears in the top, middle. That's what the painter wanted.

See the illusion. There's plentiful of churches worth a visit in Rome. The beautiful interiors are fuel for your soul and pleasure for all your senses, even for non-believers. Church of Sant'Ignazio di Loyola may not be the most significant in Rome, but do include some jewels that I'm not a specialist on. However, what I really enjoyed was the nice paintings in the ceiling that made the church feel higher then it was. The real illusion is however the "fake dome" and some come to the church just to see the illusion.

Look up. Honestly, the church isn't gorgeous by typical Roman standards. It's the ceiling that you've come to see, and it's a beauty. Make sure to try and stand on the marker in the middle of the floor to get the full effect. Simply beautiful.
Breathtaking. Amazing ceiling remains never ending picture. Visited by accident but it is worth to see as a planed point.

Happy accident. We came across this church by happy accident and nearly just walked on past. So glad we didn't. The ceiling was amazing. The model of the churches around the globe was really interesting. I can't really go into enough detail here, just make sure you make time to visit, it's a real gem.
Must see. This Church is the most fantastic and spectaculaire of Rome. Placed on a small Square close to Pantheon and Trevi. You MUST see this.

Very interesting if you like history and conspiracy theories. Came upon this church accidently while walking around Rome. I must say it is more breathtaking than the Vatican in some respects. Knowing from history that the Jesuit order was started to counteract the Reformation and that Ignazio di Loyola was at its head then the symbols around the church take on a much deeper meaning. He was the leader of the inquisition for the church. Take for instance the skull and cross bones and other related symbols on the floor, something we see even today. The medieval paintings and sculptures of him and the pope can relate his complete devotion to the papacy and thus he was thus rewarded with this church.

Don't get too sidetracked by the ceiling. The ceiling, with its optical illusions, is the most famous aspect of this church but this is just one of the magnificent pieces of art that decorate this wonderful church. Impossible to describe adequately - just go and see it.

A coat of emulsion needed?. So. a ceiling lit when you put 1 euro in the slot, which you view in a mirror set on the floor... Doesn't sound great. but you'd be wrong. It's stunning. Who can paint like that, lying on their back, for years. And the rest of the church is also stunning. Enjoy!.

Breath-takingly Beautiful - a must see. Forget the Sisteen Chapel, you must see the ceiling here! It is incredible, and a lot of the paintings look 3D, almost like statues. There are no crowds, no pushing just a peaceful and serene atmosphere. Definately worth a visit!

What a ceiling. Saw this on one of the stops on my bike tour. And it stood out as one of the more memorable church visits. The roof is amazing - the cupola that's not really there... The guys hand sticking out over the entrance. But really the paintings were awesome. My neck hurt from looking up so much. And the best part is that it was free.

My favourite church. Some of our best times in Italy were popping into less well known churches that we happened to be walking by. Of all of them, this was the best. The ceiling was really neat, it took me a while to realize that the dome was painted (perhaps going in during dusk, with not a lot of outside light, helped with the illusion). They also had a mirror set up; if you stood on the metal dot set in the floor and looked at the mirror, the ceiling mural became 3D. Very impressive.

My favorite church in Rome. By this stage in our trip I've probably seen 20+ churches in Rome including St Peter's and the Pantheon. So why is this one my favorite?It has wonderful decoration including a false dome painted on the ceiling, a very interesting model of churches from around the globe (just inside on the right) and few other tourists making it an interesting and delightful visit.

The ceiling fresco painting resembles the Sistine Chapel.. The ceiling of the Church of Sant'Ignazio is similar to the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel. A Jesuit brother painted the ceiling and included himself in the fresco peering over a railing looking down on us onlookers. Catholic mass is conducted every morning.

Great experience. Possibly the most fantastic church in Rome. Much more interesting than St. Peter's. Not too crowded, free, centrally located. Incredible ceiling (it's flat!) and way way overdone alters and paintings. Revel in the excess - it's astonishing and horrifying by today's moral standards. It was a different time and different values.
gorgeous church. What a roof. Awe inspiring. Like many churches in Rome, but better. It stands out from some of tge others.

Amazing!!!!!. Having not read any reviews for this truly beautiful church my husband and I were speechless from the moment we walked in. The ceiling (painted by Andrea Pozzo???) will take your breath away. It should be a "must do" for everyone visiting Rome. I personally would visit it again and again, no matter how many times I visited Rome. Don't miss it!

Past of power and awe coming alive. Definitely impressive as a monument to an ancient religious spirit. You understand how this kind of monuments set the illiterate in awe of the power of the church and subjugated them
Beautiful church. This was a very unusual church with an amazing painted ceiling. It is a little difficult to find but well worth it.

Hidden masterpiece. Absolutely fabulous! When you came in Rome, everybody is talking about great artists like Da Vinci, Michelangelo or Caravaggio, but did you hear anything about Andrea Pozzo? No. And that's the shame because his paintings in this church are pure masterpiece. You have to see it!
Amazing. Stunning place. Jaw dropping amount of gold, ornamentation, carvings, marble and paintings. Very well worth a visit.
Beautiful Church. Beautiful! The paintings & altars are breathtaking. Very easily accessed. Can take photographs inside this church.

Fabulous. We just happened to be passing here and so popped in for a look. In all fairness this blew me away more than the Vatican because it wasn't pitched at tourist and wasn't over crowded. The ceiling is amazing and I love the painted dome.

Awesome!. The optical illusion on the ceiling is just marvellous. We saw this as part of our tour with the new rome tours. I doubt we would have understood it by ourselves without a guide. The church itself was incredibly beautiful.
Do not miss!. This church is beautiful. We sat in awe of the perspective paintings for a really long time, and found the false dome perspective painting to be amazing.
Huge statues. My husband became an aficionado of statuary when we visited Rome. We went back several times to the Sant'Ignazio di Loyola just to marvel at the statues.

Totally mind blowing ceiling!. Many people don't bother going here as its not one of the so called "top attractions". Well you have to go just for the ceiling and "false dome" painting. It is by the acknowledged expert in Trompe L'oeil, Andrea Pozzo (he later wrote books on the subject). My brain would not believe that it was actually painted on the flat.

It's a church where you can find a lot of history. Sanit Ignazio di Loyola is one saint that I as Catholic follow so smart that has to be with education I study in one of his universities and the Pope also belong to the Jesuits order

A definite "wow". In a visit to the Eternal City which contained so many great moments, this brought forth the biggest reaction. The ceiling of this church is truly stunning (better, in my view than the Sistine Chapel, although I might be banned from Italy for saying it). A must visit.

Like the Sistine, but Free!. The exterior of this church (near the Pantheon) belies the grandeur inside. Ignatius (founder of the Jesuit Society) probably would have been a bit uncomfortable with the lavishness and immensity of this building. The fresco ceiling gives the illusion of a dome....you must see to believe it. Colorful, symbol laden, take a seat and look--there's a lot to see. Probably the most beautiful church after St. Peter's. And it's free.

Baroque Church with an interesting perspective. Yet another highly decorative Baroque church, the St Ignatius Jesuit church is memorable for its ceiling and the optical illusion within the church. The stunning frescoes on the ceiling represent St Ignatius being welcomed into heaven by Christ and the Virgin Mary. However, the really interesting thing about the church is the tromp l’oeil dome. Stand in the right place and you will be completely fooled that this is a real dome within the church. There is a marble disk in the center of the church that you must stand on. Find it and you will get the complete intended perspective of the church and its ceiling fresco. The fake dome will appear real and the figures in the frescoes seem to acquire perspective as well, moving up toward heaven. Apart from that fascinating feature, the church is like many Baroque churches in Rome with highly ornamental alters, over the top gold gilding and coloured marble.
beautiful on the inside. This out of the way church was such a surprise on the inside. Very well decorated, ceiling and all. A pleasant surprise on our walk to Piazza Navona.

An interesting church well worth the time. Set in a beautiful piazza, this church is not only beautiful but, in its architecture, almost awe inspiring. Inside is worth sitting a while and soaking in all of the history, both litergical and secular. Outside the church is a neat little restaurant with better than average food where you can enjoy the local, a smattering of tourists and the attentive owners. Worth the visit.
Worth a visit. Located in the very centre, this is an impressive example of Baroque. We admired the colours of the frescos and the magnificence of the interior. A must see, if you like Baroque

Wonderful artwork and a nice place for praying. The same Jesuit brother who painted the ceiling of the Chiesa del Gesu painted the ceiling of this Church. Very beautiful, very creative, the the "optical illusion" will blow your mind away! There are free concerts held here usually the weekend, so check the schedule. Also, don't forget to ask for a tour (it's free) of the Room(s) of St. Aloysius Gonzaga upstairs.
Very nice church. Big and beautiful church near Pantheon and Via del Corso.Amazing paintings and statues.Rome has so many churches but everyone has a different thing to see.

Breathtaking painted ceiling in this vast church. The scale and ornate detail are overwhelming. A cleverly placed mirror in the center of the floor allows you to look down and study the vast painted ceiling. A must see church in a city of beautiful churches.

Incredible!. This gem sometimes flies under the radar but it is superb. A bit unassuming from the outside, it is glorious inside. You need to look everywhere - the floors, the ceilings, the walls. It is one of the most colourful churches in Rome with great works of art. You do not want to miss it. Not at all what I expected from the Jesuits.

Hidden gem - don't miss it. We almost missed this so don't make the same mistake. The tromphe l'oiel dome is amazing and the ceiling painting is fantastic. we werer on our way from the Pantheon to the Trevi Fountain and we dived in here to get out of the rain. It was divine intervention as we were so glad we saw this. Its obviously a much smaller scale than the main sights in Rome but its worth the visit.

Sant'Ignazio di loyola. This church was recommended to us by the Concierge in our hotel. We were staying right around the corner from the churh and I would have walked right by it if he had not recommended we stop in. It is a beautiful church - with amazing frescos. Well worth a visit.
Absolutely stunning church!. Make sure you take the time to visit this church. Most of the churches in Rome are gorgeous, but this one is over the top!!

Absolutely beautiful Church near the Pantheon. I noticed this Church on Trip Advisor as it was so highly rated. I decided that this might be a real hidden gem. We walked into the Piazza dominated by this enormous Church. We walked inside and were into a new world of exquisite art and statues. The ceilings are covered in paintings and each section if the Church seems like a small museum in itself. Most if the time you walk into this type of attraction, look around quickly and are on your way. We spent better part of an hour (could have spent longer) just looking and taking pictures. Quite an amazing place!
Knockout Church. If you visit just one church in Rome, make it this one. It is genuinely unmissable and very beautiful

Worth a visit. We chanced upon this church and entered on a whim and are very glad we did as this church has some impressive murals to be marvelled at. Absolutely stunning and there is no hint of this upon arrival at the albeit good-looking yet unassuming church.

Absolutely Sumptuous!. You pass this Church going to/ from the Pantheon and the Viadel Corso. Once inside first look up at the painted ceiling with its trick 3 D effect. There are several very opulent baroque altars, including the transepts and side chapels. The church was built to commemorate the founder of the Jesuits although St Ignatius isn't actually buried here. For souvenir hunters there's a more than adequate giftshop to the left of the nave not far inside from the entrance.
beautiful. One of the most beautiful churches from the ones I visited in Rome, great ceiling, colours were wonderful, very close to Panteon.
ceiling art quite amazing. The church is like many in Rome very pretty but the ceiling artistry is worth a visit on its own. The best viewing spots are marked with yellow discs on the floor.

Amazing ceiling. All the churches in Rome are amazing but you have to see this ceiling!! The tromp l'oeil effects are wonderful. Just take time to sit and look. The figures appear to be falling out of the ceiling on to you...and it cost nothing!!

A hidden gem. This was one of my favourite places in Rome. I sought it out after reading a review on Trip Advisor, and I was so delighted I had gone to the trouble to find it. The interior is amazing, the paintings are stunning. I would go as far as to rate it higher than the Sistine Chapel.
WOW. There are hundreds of Churches in Rome. All have something to offer, but we had to pick. Our sister-in-law said we should not miss this one and she was right. The ceiling is amazing.
Little Gem. Raphael fresco's, 3D ceiling fresco - beautiful. Central and easy to get to and free of charge. Fascinating
Beautiful Church. This was our 2nd visit to this beautiful church. The ceiling is gorgeous and the dome is not to be missed.

Peace, perfect Peace. A beautiful church full of magnificent art work. Also a place of spirituality and peace. You can attend Mass in a side chapel, 4 times a day, and go to Confession. Well worth a visit.

Great surprise. Seems to be pretty ordinary from outside. Wow, what a surprise inside. The interior rivals any church in Rome with the exception of St. Peter's. Eight side altars and an awesome main altar. A must see !

Church of Saint Ignazio di Loyola. Famous church. Rich and interesting. The sculpture of St. Ignazio is showing every day at 17.30h. Pleasant horals . Great attraction! If you visit Rome find an hour to see it.
spectacular. Chanced on this by accident although it is a major tourist attraction! As with all churches in Rome spectacular ...look out for the painted 'dome' on the ceiling!
Fantastic. Must go inside to appreciate beautiful art. Fantastic - not far from hotel. Overlooking piazza with fountains

Surprise Package. On the exterior it looks like thousands of other smaller churches in Roman. On the interior are frescoes and paintings to rival the best. Worth stopping for (and it is on one of the tourist tracks connecting P. Navona and the Pantheon.
somewhere between baroque and rococco. A stunning ceiling, tombs of several important Jesuit saints and a beautifully designed building make it a draw.

The best thing in Rome hands down. The ceiling is just a masterpiece....I feel lucky to have seen it and feel everyone who visits Rome should take time out to sit in quiet appreciation of this church.
Amazing trompe l'oeil ceiling. So easy to miss this treasure. Ceiling is simply incredible. Be prepared for a pain in your neck from looking up at it.
Wow. Amazing. Spectacular.. Wandered in almost by accident to be met with the most amazingly decorated church you could imagine. Absolutely should be on any Rome list
Amazing!!! The top of all churches ive seen in rome!. Amazing architecture and art. Really spiritual place. Less touristic than the other holly places around rome.

Just another 'minor' church. Beautiful baroque church on a slightly quiet but impressive baroque square in the middle of Old Rome.
Great frescoes celebrating Sant'Ignazio di Loyola and the power of the Jesuits and an absolutely amazing tromp-l'oeil dome painting.
Beautiful church. Had a view of the rooftop of this church from our hotel terrace. Very plain from the outside but stunning inside with the fantastic ceiling. Well worth a visit.
Mirrors. So good that they have mirrors to view the church ceiling - blown away by it hidden gem near the pantheon

Amazing Church. Beautiful interior and artwork well worth a visit especially if you went to a Jesuit School. Tomb of Saint Ignatius is amazing. Society of Jesus is right next door. Women will not be admitted wearing shorts or if they have bare shoulders.

Hidden gem. Not an outstanding building from the outside but the interior is amazing with its fabulous artwork. The depiction of a false dome is very clever - you need to move around the church to recognize this.

Beautiful church! . We stumbled upon this church by accident while walking around to visit other places. It is one of the most beautiful churches I've ever seen. We also visited the Sistine Chapel and I feel like this compares to the beauty there. If you are walking around and find yourself in the vicinity of this church, you should definitely go in and take a peak!

If you're into paintings and churches this is it. Beautiful paintings on the ceiling, and lovely place just to visit on your way to the more known attractions of Rome.Negative few spots that still needed finishing touches

Better than Sistine Chapel!. Well, not definitatively better, my wife perfered the sistine chapen, however I though this was had the more impressive ceiling. However what is not in conjection is that they are more massively impressive and that this one is a must, espeically considering you can you want in (no queing like at the Vatican). Must see.

Stunning!. Stumbled across this church whilst looking for other sites. My actual words to my wife prior to entering it were "Is it worth looking in?". Upon entering, we both shared a chuckle as we looked up at the ceiling. The building, the decoration, the sheer awe inspiring scale inside is absolutely incredible. If you are anywhere near this church, make sure you pay it a visit.Literally INCREDIBLE.

Beautiful. We stumbled on this place while lost and were amazed how somewhere so breathtakingly beautiful could be tucked away in the small streets, we actually appreciated it more than St Peters (which IMO only just beats it) as it was so peaceful. If you're in Rome it's well worth looking for.

My #1 favorite Church in Rome. I loved visiting this church. My favorite church in Rome by far. The painting on the ceiling is amazing. As you walk in and look up the painting has movement. A real treat to see and not very crowded because it's not a "popular" church to visit which is why I wanted to see it. My 10 year old son was amazed by this church as well.

Stunning ceiling!!. We had been told to visit this church due to the spectacular painting on the ceiling and I'm glad, as if we had not been told about it, we would have walked straight past!
