The building does not really seem much from the outside but when you step inside and look up... wow! Simply breathtaking! If you are in Rome, do not miss a visit to this beautiful church.
One of my favourites in Rome!. Sant'Ignazio di Loyola Church is an amazingly beautiful church, one of my favourites in Rome! It well deserves a visit!

Don't Pass This By, Stop and be amazed.. Simply stunning church, incredible frescoes on the ceiling, multiple domes and has several side chapels. So beautiful and breathtaking. We visited several churches in Italy but only St. Peters surpassed this church in my opinion. It is just beautiful. The outside won't grab your attention but the inside will amaze you. Make the trip here if you are in Rome, don't leave without visiting. Very near to the Pantheon and our hotel.

Tucked away in the backstreets - a real gem. With so many great and historic churches, it is hard to pick a few but this one must be on the top of any list. Highly unusual in its design and execution - a fitting tribute to St. Ignazio

Peace in the city.. We happened upon this church while exploring the Pantheon area. We entered thinking we would have a quick look, then move on. It was so beautiful and peaceful we stayed for nearly an hour.
Beautiful church. Found this church by accident while looking for the Pantheon. Glad we did, one of the nicest churches we saw while touring Italy.

Stunning. It's so easy to just walk by this church as we did, many times! Don't make that mistake, it really is a gem. Beautifully decorated, ornate chapel altars that each deserve a look and ceilings that are simply breathtaking. Be sure to go to the circle on the floor in the centre of the church see the "dome" at the right angle. Amazing.

Beautiful. I have learned about the painted illusion of the dome in this church in my Art History class. It is amazing to finally see it in person. Overall, it is a gorgeous Baroque building, I couldn't stop taking photos and videos inside!

Takes your breath away. I know I am echoing many previous review here, but they are accurate. From the outside this church looks nothing special, just one of many churches in Rome, the facade is large but unprepossessing and it resides in a quiet, small piazza - something of a backwater. But walk inside - the ceiling just makes your jaw drop. The 3D effect is astonishing, the figures just seem to float in the air, there are curves and perspectives that you know don't actually exist but they look as though they are really there. I was just amazed at the skill and artistry of the painter. There is a yellow marble spot in the centre - stand there to appreciate the perspective.Not to be missed.
Another free tourist attraction in Rome. Another impressive church in Rome. Free to visit and gives you an opportunity to cool down...........

Not to be Missed church. When in the neighborhood of the Pantheon in Rome, a short distance away is The Jesuit Church of Sant'Ignazio di Loyola. Built in the first half of the 1600's it contains marvelous frescoes and sculptures. The ceiling was painted by Andrea Pozzo and is wonderful to view from the marble disc in the middle of the nave as it creates an illusion of depth. To fully appreciate all to see in then church, I would advice Googling it for explanations of what you will see. I viewed the paintings and wondered how they could be executed all the way up to the very high ceiling.

Amazing church. Eventhough from the outside, this church doesnt look nice at all. When we went inside we were surprised ... amazing painting on the ceilings... amazing wall paintings... everything was sooo nice

a musical find!. We were walking past the church and our son, 27 and a great singer, heard music thru the open doors and dashed in. The National Sacred Music Choir from Korea was performing, and we thoroughly enjoyed the wonderful concert! The church is lovely, too, with beautiful side altars and much art throughout.
The ceiling alone is worth dropping in. This place was beautiful, really took us by surprise. The ceiling is incredible. One of my favorite basilicas.
Beautiful inside. If in Rome, check it out. Beautiful inside with fantastic paintings on the ceilings and some fantastic carved statues.

Ceiling and dome incredible!. I am certainly no art expert but the perspective painted into the ceiling and the dome (that's not a dome) is amazing. Forget the hype of the Sistine Chapel. I much preferred this ceiling

The outside hides the beauty of the inside. When passing in front of this Church you must feel inclined to not to enter in it due to the appearance of it from outside. DO be assertive and get in... I bet that by the time you put your feet into it you will be amazed... tha paintings on the top and all around it will leave you staggered... pay attention to the 3-D techniques already developed in such a long time ago...
Another church in Rome. Rome is full of ancient churches, so this is just one of them. I liked the surroundings and just to stay outside.
Beautiful renaissance church. Amazing a must see, not far from Pantheon. Ceilings and domes so so beautiful and a very clever optical illusion..read Rick Steves pocket Rome guide.

The nave ceiling!!. Ignatius of Loyola, the founder of Society of Jesus (S.J. or Jesuits) and after his canonization in the 17th century, Pope Gregory XV suggested a church should be dedicated to the saint...as you walk in you'll be feasting on visual sumptuosity - colored marbles, rich ornamentings, extensive gildings... but look up head, the breath-taking nave ceiling fresco by andrea Pozzo - St. Ignazio being welcomed to heaven by Jesus and Virgin Mary. This is the highlight! This is the crown jewel of the church!By the way, it is withing 10 min. walking from the Fontana di Trevi and at the same piazza (di S. Ignazio), located a famous ristorante - Le Cave di S. Ignazio Ristorante Pizzeria. You'd be sorry if you miss it!

Beautiful ceiling. This church is very impressive, we were advised to see it by our Segway guide - we stopped outside it on a night time tour of the city and decided to go back through the day when it was open to see inside. There is an ideal point on the floor from which to view the ceiling which is amazing.
Absolutely Stunning. Just wow, it is part of a few buildings that are jaw-dropping in Rome. Go see it, you will not be disappointed.
History is amazing.. I am not a religious person but found this very interesting. Every corner brings a new experience. The artwork is very intricate.
Stunning church. I am a fan of Saint Ignatius, as he is the patron saint of the Casa di Dom Ignazio in Brazil. This church is stunning inside and worth a visit while vising the Pantheon in Rome

Not well known; but took my breath away. St. Ignazio may not be the most well known church in Rome, but it may have been one of my favorite spots to visit. Simply beautiful, with gorgeous artwork on all of the side altars and on the ceiling. My favorite part of this was looking at the Faux Dome that was painted on the inside. Brilliant and beautiful, I had to check twice outside that there was no actual dome....While every church we visited was beautiful, this actually surprised me in how great it was
Stunning Church. The dome, which is an optical illusion and is actually a flat roof which has been painted is a must to see.

A nice little find.... We found this church by chance, on our way to the pantheon. It is quite stunning inside and out. The outside boasts traditional architecture and the inside is decorated with beautiful paintings covering the ceiling. My favourite part was the interesting wooden model on the inside to the right with churches all around the world with their architectural designs to be compared.
Perspective. It has a painted cupola that resembles a real one, its amazing.you stand in different places and you enjoy different perspectives.interesting frescoes also.

Overwhelmingly beautiful. We recently spent 12 days in Rome, highlighted by visits to many of this city's Catholic churches, chapels, cathedrals and basilicas. Without a doubt, Loyola's is the most memorable. Spend some time before your visit reading this saint's biography and the rich meaning behind the Jesuit tenets: your efforts will be rewarded as the story inside the church will unfold. Only caveat about the church, be aware of when Mass is offered, as visitors are not allowed during that time, but attendees/communicants are.

Fascinating. We stumbled over this church on our way to Phantenon. Actual cause for entrance where shelter in 32 degree heat, but we got stuck for roundabout 1 hour. Impressive paintings and decorations, especially the marble on the walls. It's hard to understand how they succeded to build it in the 16:th century.

My favorite church in Rome. This is my favorite church in Rome. Not because is the most stunning, and there are many more famous ones. But the atmosphere, combined with the fact that it is actually used by roman catholics make it a sure recommendation. The combination of the most amazing roof Frescoes of Andrea Pozzo, and the architectural grandeur of the church, drawn up by the Jesuit mathematician, Orazio Grassi, make for a must see.

Attractive and traditional. If you are spending a day visiting several of Romes many beautiful churches, the memories of Sant Ignazio di Loyola may become clouded by the grander frescoes and side chapels of some or by the more peaceful aspects of others. It has more tourist visitors than I'd have expected and despite its origins has liitle that is artistically different or spectacular. However, it remains one of my top ten tourist churches in Rome, but not one that I would choose to visit if I was on a tight schedule.
stunning dome. we came across this church by chance. it was nice, full of frescoes and wery impressive dome creating illusions.

And not crowded. Our visit to this church was chosen for the fact that its not on the usual tourist list of places to see. It's a wide spectacular church with its amazing ceiling painting, that tricks the eye! Easy to find, it's less than 5minutes walk from The Pantheon.
Stunning!. Went here on a free walking tour of Rome and wows beautiful! It's worth a look inside just for the ceiling and optical illusion! Hidden gem!

Better than you think. Amazing jewel just off Via Del Corso on the way to the Pantheon. Sensational detail inside. We arrived just at the end of a wedding which was held there and then a mass began. You can't take pics during the mass due to respect and protocol issues. Very happy we saw this.

Breath taking. You could almost miss this place as you walk through the square but once you are inside you will be amazed at the breath taking beauty and size of the church. The painted ceiling is incredible and the 'fake' dome is very clever.When we went in August it was very busy but because of the size of the building it does not feel overcrowded.There was no charge to enter.
One of the most beautiful churches I have ever seen. From the outside this looks like nothing special, but when you walk in, WOW, the ceilings and paintings are just truly breathtaking

spectacular. the vault of the main nave of the church will leave you open-mouthed, three-dimensional effect of the painting is really amazing, as it remains difficult to imagine that the hand of man lying on a scaffold is able to realizare work so great. Also worth a visit even the apse and the central dome, as well as the quiet square opposite the church.
Lovely Church. Make sure you stand on the yellow dot to see the mural from the correct perspective. The ceiling becomes truly 3D.
Che soffitto!. What a ceiling! You could spend hours looking at the three dimensional detail ( and the phony dome).

Wonderful Church. My brothers graduated from a Jesuit high school (Jesuit - New Orleans). My husband and I both graduated from a Jesuit college. (Spring HIll College) And my brothers sons both attend a Jesuit school currently. We all felt very connected in this church. It is beautiful! Definitely check it out.

Beauty within. We nearly walked past this amazing church on our way from the Pantheon to the Trevi Fountain and ducked in at the last moment. It is amazing inside, with beautiful chapels around the edges and frescos on the ceiling.
Is a very small church. Is near the pantheon but quite hard to find as it is in those alleys. Is small but worth a visit since you are around Pantheon but is dark inside.
beautiful. An absolute delight to see this church, not far from piazza nano a. One of the most beautiful churches I have ever seen

Hidden beauty. This is an amazingly decorated church, although you won't expect such beauty when you're standing outside of the building. I didn't expect. But i guess every church in Rome is full of surprises. The panting on the ceiling is beath-taking - it's painted in 3D, all colorful and full of various scenes. And the church is huge! I didn't expect also the size of the building.To get there, you should follow the signs to the Pantheon from Via del Corso. It's on the way to the Pantheon. So when walking there, you definitely have to visit Church of Sant' IGnazio di Loyola.
A limitless wonder of the usual tourist pathways. A beautiful church and deceptively large. Worth a visit tucked in the small but charming Piazza with da Sabatino restaurant outside for sustenance.

The best ceiling in Rome. This hidden gem contains the best artwork in Rome, the ceiling by Andrea pozzo makes the Sistine look like a children's colouring book, the use of illusion will blow you away, a dome on a flat roof is staggering. This is a Rome must see location
Gorgeous. Gorgeous roof. Go see the roof!! It's another beautiful church in Rome, but the roof is spectacular. Why isn't it as famous as the roof in the sixtine chapel?

A must visit!. I've walked past this basilica many times on the way to the Pantheon from the Trevi Fountain and decided to take a look inside. Wow! Rome amazes me with the wonderful places one seems to just stumble upon. From the outside it doesn't look like much and unless you stand across the Piazza Ignatius you won't even notice it's a basilica. If you love Bernini you must put this on your list of places to visit. Don't miss the ceiling paintings. for me it is just as spectacular as the Sistine Chapel.

What an optical illusion!. Enter this very building and walk straight ahead, stand on the yellow spot and look up. What looks like a dome shape above you is actually a flat mural painted to trick the eye! Stunning! Also take some time to look around too as there are other beautiful things to see here too. Located between Via del Corso and the Pantheon.
what a ceiling. be aware of the hours usually closed at noon. the painting on the ceiling is just amazing. the sculptures just makes you want to say wow!

Mouth dropping as you enter and observe the opulence. Beautiful church deceptively large inside and quite stunning. Very baroque and decorative. You won't believe the fact the the ceiling mural, painted by a Jesuit named Pozzi, is flat. So to overcome this situation ( it seems domed us better ) he painted it to give you the impression that it was curved. Unbelievable. Look carefully you think some of the legs stick out as if they are part sculptures. Around the side are interesting Chapels containing various saints. TIP you may find a man outside requesting a fee, we think he is begging but are unsure if that.
Interesting history. The Christian democracy was born here!, very beautiful church but nothing special in a place like Rome.

An unassuming outside but an amazingly beautiful inside. As with many Roman churches it seems, the outside of this church is very unassuming, so much so that you might pass right by it without stopping to look at what's inside. The inside is quite beautiful, however, with wonderful murals painted behind the baptistry and on the ceilings. You probably have never heard of the Jesuit artist who is responsible for these magnificent art works, but I promise you that you will not be disappointed.

The Dome's Cupola is All Illusion. As you enter the large church you'll see what appears to be a cupola in the dome. Keep on looking. It's not, just what a clever artist or architect created hundreds of years ago to give the appearance.
Do not miss this beautiful church in Rome. An absolute delight to see this church, not far from piazza nano a. One of the most beautiful churches I have ever seen.

Good one!. This church around the top 5 of all churches in romeI can recommend it fully and u wont regret it if u visit the placeU can also admire tiny examples of some of the most famous churches, and mosques all over the worldAlso the roof looks absolutely stunning from the inside and all the paintings and statues are also greatNo entrance fees and u can enter with a short trouser (men)Women will get a tunic to cover hot pens and tops
Must see hidden gem. Some of the most beautiful frescoes you will see anywhere. For an amateur art lover they are comparable with artwork in sistine chapel.

amazing organ player. This was our last stop that day and the evening mass was on so we stayed. The church is just amazing. There are several Jesuit saints buried there (among them St. Gonzaga). The organ music at the end of the mass was mind blowing --it was an uplifting experience. This is one of 5 churches one must see in Rome (the others: St. Peter In Chains; The Gesu-nearby as well as Pantheon, and lastly St Maria Maggiore).

I could lay on the floor staring at this masterpiece for days. You must go see this. It is awe inspiring. It is a show of brilliant technique and of general brilliance. It is so beautiful. You will be in shock at the spectacularness of it. Please go!!!

Well worth seeking out for the amazing "special effects" ceiling. We'd read about the 17th century Baroque church before we left home and decided it was worth taking the time to find for curiosity's sake. It exceded all expecations. Wow. What a spectacular sight! If you stand in the centre of the nave and look straight up, it looks like the figures are floating in mid-air. Stand on the marble circle in the floor and the false dome looks perfect. But as you approach the chancel, you see the effect is completely an optical illusion created by false perspective in the painting. Church is free to visit; a few coins in the slot will illuminate the dome. Well worth your time.

One of Romes top 5 churches. The church of Sant'Ignazio di Loyola is one of Romes most beautifull. I might even argue that it has the most beautifull roof painting of all churches I've seen i Rome. It is easy to find the church and inside a calm and cool atmosphere will greet you. Take a deep breath, slide down and sit like a tean ager in one of the wooden benches and look up at the roof.
Impressive. Though in Rome terms just a tad above average. Lovely large painting on the ceiling. Right in the center of the city. Worth a visit while nearby.

Sistine Chapel-like ceiling with less crowds. The false dome and the intricacy of the ceiling at Sant'Ignazio rivals the Sistine Chapel. Right near the Pantheon, it's an easy stop to make when visiting the big sights in Rome. Definitely put this on your to-do list.
Wonderful. The brave attempt to go 3D on the ceiling with pictures of lofty domes while actually it's quite flat on the outside. I found it more interesting that the Sistine Chapel and more personal.
Large Church. The church was very beautiful and easy to manage. There was quite a crowd, but it was comfortable to walk around and view the entire church.

Great for non-church people. The art in the church makes it a must-see. The interior is very theatrical and makes quite an impression for all visitors. The ceiling is by far the best part and should not be missed if in this part of Rome.

Another superb church. Rome is full of beautiful churches and Sant'Ignazio is superb. Spacious, light and bright. There is a fabulous painted ceiling which will hold your attention for quite some time. I visited just after opening and was one of three people there. It was a lovely experience.

Speechless. As soon as you walk in this amazing church, you will be amazed by the painting on the celling, we were there for a long time, and can't get our eyes off this painting, it is unreal, is a must visit.

Most beautiful church in a Rome!. Breathtakingly beautiful. We were there about 10am and the morning sun was beaming through the windows with the most beautiful rays! A magnificent display of art. Definitely worth your time!
incredible. If interested in art and arthistory as well as contra-reformation, do visit this church! The art works are incredible!

Fascinating church. There is a point in the middle of the floor, which is supposed to be the best for viewiing the ceiling. I was there on an overcast day with some bursts of light. SO I did only see the brilliance very briefly. But a fascinatingly beautiful church.

Extraordinarily beautiful. The roof, painted by Pozzo, gives the Sistine Chapel a run for its money! Don't give money to the guy on the door - I'm sure it's a scam. There are donation boxes inside. For Ignatian spiritualists, knowing the remains of Saint Aloysius Gonzaga are here, is very moving.

Imposing outside, incredibly beautiful and peaceful inside. You have to put this 17th century church on in the middle of your path as you must get inside to fully absorb what this Church offers - it usually closes at 7PM (as any other church) but worth Googling for it just in case.The strongest points are- no fees (as any other normal church!)- wheelchair access (very useful for the stroller) - the model of the "Temple of Christ", which doesn't have much info but seems to be a model containing references to all religions, bringing them into a kind of ecumenism. San Ignacio is the founder of the Society of Jesus (a.k.a. Jesuits) so anything related to Jesuits brings you to him.- the "dome", which is actually a 3D paint- the awesome ceiling frescoes painted by Andrea Pozzo (on the 17th century)- the peaceful you'll find inside the church, especially if you went to Sistine Chapel or San Peter's Basilica that are heavily crowded
I enjoyed the old castle. I experienced real old castle though many eurpean catles were rebuilt.

Magnificent and breathtaking. The ceiling of this church is simply breathtaking. It is like the nowadays three dimensional effect and is unbelievable that someone could do that back then. They put a magnifying mirror on the floor so you can look up the ceiling and get the full experience. This is nowhere to be seen elsewhere except in Rome - the Sistine chapel, the great room at Barberini Palace and this - personally it was that took my breath away on my trip to Rome. It is very close to the Pantheon so you should make the detour on your next visit to Rome.

Accidental Discovery - Worth a Visit. Location: Not too far from the Pantheon. I came across this church quite by accident and saw that the doors were open so naturally, I had to go investigate. The place: Let's be honest - is there any church in Rome that's NOT worth a visit? Even the smallest church seems to be rich with beauty and history so my rule quickly became 'If the door's open, walk on in.' I thought this church was quite beautiful and it reminded me a little of San Giovanni. This was one of those places that you can enter and immediately find relief from the hordes of tourists wandering around the Centro Storico. The church was surprisingly big, and had amazing ceilings. Definitely worth a visit if you are in the area. Price point: Free entry.

AWE INSPIRING!. Although not Catholic, I am a great fan of Ignatius of Loyola and those members of the Society of Jesus. This church is incredibly awe inspiring. My wife and I were there on a Saturday and witnessed high mass at noon. To hear the organ and the great acoustics was a particular gift when surrounded by such beauty. I was amazed to find the church was rated number six out of over 700 sites in Rome. However, it is certainly deserving of this high ranking and I recommend it highly.

Better than the Sistine. On a personal score - loved it better than the Sistine as it was quite to a pindrop, absolutely no crowds, serene, no entry fees, the paintings and frescos are awesome and personally to me who is not an art critic better to the eyes than the Sistine chapel at Vatican, and its on the way of other tourist attractions along the Via del Corso . Don't ever miss it !!

Simply gorgeous. Shouldn't miss it if you're anywhere nearby. We happened upon this church after leaving the Pantheon and en route to another stop. We peeked inside and were astonished. It's enormous with a spectacular ceiling and beautiful artwork. It's worth a visit.
Jaw dropping ceiling!. Beautiful church. All Rome's churches are stunning but the ceiling in here is quite incredible. Use the mirrors to look in detail.
Wonderful Church to Stumble Upon. This beautiful church is near the more-visited Pantheon, but was so peaceful and beautiful inside. The art-filled church was amazing to view.
Gorgeous ceiling frescoes. Near the Pantheon. Beautifully frescoed ceilings, and they even have mirrors so you don't have to look up and strain your neck. Baroque style, so a bit over the top.

No dome?. This church is fascinating. The jesuits had their astronomical instruments on the roof because the dome was never built. From the meteorological station they told the guys on the Gianicolo hill on the other side of town when it was noon and time to shoot off the cannon. You can still see the tower Calandrelli where they did this from the back side of the church above the Collegio Romano - precursor to the Gregorian University.

Another amazing church!!. Unbelievably big, beautiful & blessed! We love visiting these peaceful, serene & art-filled churches. Each one as amazing (or more so!) than the last, the next! We always say a quick prayer of thanks that they're still around & that we are able to see them!

Art, history, central location. We happened upon this church unknowingly while strolling so decided to stop in. Glad we did. The art, architecture, history, etc. is to marvel at while relaxing in a cool, peaceful church. Very close to the Pantheon so it's quite convenient to make a quick stop while sightseeing. The only downside was we gave a donation to a doorman of sorts on the way in and on the way out a different doorman sought donations a bit too aggressively for my taste, but we just kept walking.

Like the Sistine Chapel. This church is absolutely beautiful. The paintings on the ceiling rival those found in the Sistine Chapel. The whole church is absolutely stunning. It is located nearby the Pantheon, so why not stop in after your visit to the Pantheon
stunning. excellent architecture, lovely ceilings, there is beauty where ever you turn. they have even set up mirrors so that we can enjoy the ceiling without a crick in the neck. NOT to be missed

It's free and awe inspiring!. Why would you not go? Free guides were even advertised during our stop by. We stayed for about 15-20 minutes, easily found seats, and enjoyed the cool air while gazing at the ceiling. So impressive!! But, you don't have to strain your neck the whole time, there is a magnifying mirror which takes the experience to another level! Be sure to stand on the red star in the center of the aisle to get the best view of the "dome!"

Worth the look (up). This was recommended by a guide who told us only that there was an optical illusion. There certainly was! In a city of churches, this one was amazing. Around the walls are the standard church-y things: statues, graves, side chapels, etc, but look up and you'll see something altogether different (I won't spoil the surprise, though). Definitely worth visiting.

Don't forget to look up!. This place is completely and totally awe-inspiring. It takes your breath away. You will get a stiff neck if you do this church properly, because you will be gaping at the ceiling for impressive and probably unhealthy amounts of time. Time loses meaning in here; it's just so gorgeous. A must-see.
A bit over the top. Rather ornate for a northern European taste. Suggest slightly more out of the way the smaller Sant'Andrea al Quirinale by Bellini
Another opulent place of worship. This was a beautiful church with magnificent emerald marble and an amazing fresco. Worth a gander when you are near the Pantheon.
A must for any Jesuit school grad. The false dome that was painted to make it appear tall was a work of art . The Basilica was amazing as well.

Stunning church!. We bumped into this church by accident, and we were so happy we stopped. Incredible inside, we also preferred it to the renovated Sistine Chapel. Very few people inside.
Try to see it if you have time.
Beautiful Church. A beautiful church with amazing baroque illusions making flat walls and ceilings appear 3-d. The interior is a work of art in a city of art.

Unbelievable effects. We wandered in here en route to Trevi. Mum came rushing out and insisted we get up off steps and go in. The ceiling and faux done are works of genius and need to be seen to be believed.

stunning. It took us a while to find this church but worth it in the end the interior are nothing short of spectacular. The ceilings in the dome are stunning. I preferred them to the Sistine Chapel. A short walk from the Pantheon & a must see if you like art & churches.

Truly Amazing. Located near the Pantheon, This is one of the best interiors of all the churches I’ve been. Once inside, you will be truly amazed of the beauty of the church. The façade of the church does not look big but when inside you’ll be astound how big this church is. It is free to enter the church and photos are allowed. I think St. Peter’s Basilica is the best, but this is one of the nicest churches in Rome.
Interesting. This church is interesting as a church but particularly worth seeing the optical allusion of the dome and ceiling. A covenient stop between the Pantheon and Piazza navonna.

Much better experience than St Peters Basilica. This church is stunning, the place has a very serene atmosphere and for me, it is a better church to visit than St Peters Basilica, which is enormous - too big, there are too many people and it is just like a huge building, I did not feel any spirituality in the St Peters Basilica, but here, you really feel at peace.

An impressive painting in the ceiling. One of the most beautiful churches in Rome - It impresses mainly by the painting in the ceiling: a perfect tridimensional view on a flat ceiling. It is near the Panteon and the Piazza Navona, so don't miss it!

Best of Andrea pozzo. This is one of the most impressive ceiling works that one gets to see after Sistine chapel and the work of andrea pozzo is not only captive but also gives an amazing visual effect while you are inside the chapel. Not only is the chapel credited with the beautiful fresco but also works in statue like della strada. Sant’ignazio di Loyola is a Jesuit church that acted as the chapel for the roman college closeby . The church is in honor of St Ignatius. As much as the chapel looks plain from outside, the interiors will blind you with its interior works.

Beautiful church- check out the ceiling!. Look at the way the designer used illusion in the ceiling... If it's hot outside this is a great place to cool off too. Peaceful. Only enter if you are properly dressed (no shorts etc.)

Beautiful historical hotel. Historically, very interesting. Beautiful. Read about it before you visit, including getting some tidbits about St Ignatius. Very. Close to the Pantheon. Nothing to dislike.

The Paintings!. when you think that you have seen enough churhces in Rome, St. Ignazio surprises you. The frescos on the cielings are incredible. The piaza outside is just impecable, and you can have a quick bite to eat on a terraza right there.
A gem just a stones throw from the Pantheon. If you are in this area near the Pantheon you must go and see it its a gem , it is so ornate and inspiring

Don't miss this one!. This church is wonderful. It is not crowded. It is free to enter and a much more pleasant experience than the Sistine Chapel. The ceiling is much more impressive than the Sistine Chapel.
Visit and stand in awe!. Stunning. Incredible history, art and architecture. Sit quietly in a side chapel and take it all in as you contemplate your existence.
Beautiful church!. This church may look simple from the outside but don't let the simple facade fool you. Inside it is beautiful! The architecture and ceiling paintings just wow. A must see!
Beautiful church. Really beautiful, well decorated, gorgeous! I liked very much to see it in this trip. I recommed the visit for catholic people.

A special interest destination. This church was founded by St. Ignatius himself and contains, among other things, the restored icon of the Madonna della Strada which was important to him. The Carvaggio mentioned in many guidebooks is no longer there, but the church is still of interest to anyone who is a friend of the Jesuits or related Ignatian organizations.

Beautiful Trompe L'Oeil Ceiling. My guide took me to this church as part of a walking tour. I highly recommend coming here to see the painted ceiling by Boromini. Wouldn't have missed this for the world!

Don't miss this!. Walking tour guide took us here... amazing ceiling. One part of ceiling looks like you're looking at dome but it's flat, guide tells story why. Tomb of the pope is amazing too, marble carved to look like drapes.

Truly beautiful. I picked up the details for this church on Trip Advisor before my husband and I went to Rome last month (April). When I suggested it the said he wasn't interested in churches and the "religious stuff"! However, after he saw the inside of this church we visited 5 more during our trip! This church is truly stunning and worth the effort. Add it to your list of "to do's" under "hidden gems"!
Fake dome. May not be the most famous church in Rome but it is a must see, especially the wonderfully painted fake dome
Baroque splendour. The trompe l'oeile Baroque ceiling is incredible by Boromini is absolutely amazing. Check out the dome.
The amazing ceiling. This church had an amazing ceiling painted to look like it was domed or in 3-D. Also painted an imitation of a dome that looks very real.

Very lovely church. The interior is just amazing. The entrance was nice like most churches but then the interior clearly knocked the wind out of me. The roof was intricately designed with such artistic work I had my head craned up the entirety of the visit. It was a great opportunity to visit this church especially since my family went to a jesuit school and he was their patron saint. It isnt exactly one of the places everyone is excited to go to, but it is worth visiting.
Fabulous church. Churches in Rome are mind blowing and this one will certainly meet your expectations with paintins, mozaics etc by the score.

Great example of Baroque taste. Although not the masterpiece of Baroque architecture and art found in its sister-church de Gesu, the church of Saint Ignatius Loyola is a must see. The experience begins in the charmingly theatrical pizza in front of it. Once inside the efforts of architect Carlo Moderno and Orazio Grassi (who designed the facade) can not but create a sense of awe. The artwork of the apse and ceilings vaults are breath-taking examples of Baroque sentiments, great achievements by Andrea Pozzo. Note the marvelous trompe l'oeil that gives the impression that there is acupola on the church. There is none, but Pozzo makes us believe there is. Yes, it another ornate church in Rome. But if you are equipped with a little knowledge about Baroque art and a little knowledge about the church before you enter it, you will appreciate it all the more.

heavenly. We had the absolute pleasure to visit the church this month for a concert given by my daughters school choir. After a day trawling round the Vatican and Sistine chapel I have to say Sant'Ignazio proved to be much more impressive! It's a gem that could be easily over looked on the typical tourist trail. Take time out to visit. Along with the Pantheon, it was a highlight for us.

Beautiful interior. This church is worth a visit because of the wonderful paintings on the high ceiling. An added extra is a large mirror on the floor which magnifies the paintings. The whole building is very ornate inside, but the plain exterior might lead you to pass it by. Close to other attractions such as the Pantheon and Trevi Fountain so include it on your route. FREE TO ENTER.

Beautiful Novelty. The Church of Saint Ignazio of Loyola is beautiful in its own right and like many of the churches in Rome, it is an active place of worship with significant numbers of tourists taking time to meditate and pray in quiet reverence. But the church, while beautiful, is also a novelty with its faux dome painted by Andreas Pozzo, a Jesuit priest, when money ran out to provide a real dome. Another story is that the dome could not be built because it would have exceeded the height of the dome of Saint Peters and that was not allowed. I subscribe to the former because there are two finished domes in the church along with the faux dome.The artwork is so deceiving that not being aware of it, one might simply assume the dome is a real dome and not give it a second thought.While this church is named for Saint Ignazio, founder of the Jesuits, his remains are actually entombed in the Gesu Church a couple of blocks away though this church does house the remains of Pope Gregory XV.While it is certainly worth a visit, I was surprised to learn that this church is the #4 attraction in Rome, apparently far more popular than Saint Peters Basilica and the Pantheon, a block away, which ranks only at #9 and even though both have considerably more historical significance.

Impressive place, but I don't like Baroque. A very impressive place, probably the most baroque church of Rome. The most important place inside the church is probably the memorial for Ignatius of Loyola, the founder of the Society of Jesus. Since I'm a protestant I might not have a sense for Baroque and its golden splendour. However it's a good place to see the ecclesia triumphans of the Counter-Reformation and as it is a church that's not among the most watched in Rome, you should go there as well.
Dome!. we went there on the way going to the Pantheon from Trevi Fountain.the painting are stunning,with details and special colors.the ceiling worth visit even after a neck ache!:)

Faux dome!. As soon as you walk in, look to the dome. It is a serious illusion and one to be admired. The Jesuit artist, Pozzo, who designed and painted it surely was a genius of light and perspective.
Simply brilliant. You MUST visit this incredible church in the heart of Roma. It is so ornate and beautifully decorated - you will be amazed. Well worth the visit.
Beautiful. Gorgeous little Church. Very quiet and peaceful and a real escape from the hustle and bustle of Roma!
Wonderful ceiling. Don't miss this near the Pantheon. The three dimensional mural on the ceiling is amazing and you won't have to wait three hours to get in.

Beautiful!. Absolutely astounding church, with beautiful marble floors and walls, a wonderful painted ceiling and lovely sculptures. It's situated really close to the pantheon, so well worth a visit once you're in the area!

Look up. One of so many beautiful churches in Rome. The cupola one expects to see here was never built - because no church might be higher then st. Petr basilica - so in its place, Andrea Pozzo supplied a painting on canvas with a perspectival projection of a cupola. Amazing!
Beautiful church. Fascinating church, really interesting, a holy place. We found it by accident and we were so glad that we did.

Amazing art and beautiful marble. This is an outstanding church. The paintings all around the church are magnificent. The sculptures are very nicely displayed. And the marble columns and other structures (mostly redish pink) are very impressive.
Stop in!. This place was in a quiet neighborhood and wasn't crowded. The inside was beautiful and serene. You should definitely stop in and look around.

Treasure of the churches. The first time I came here was on a school trip to Rome, but this was without a doubt a gem I will never forget. It's a must see for everyone, even though you don't like visiting churches, this one (except for the Sankt Peters) is a definite MUST. The ceiling is something you can gaze at for a long time. I returned on my latest trip, and on my Rome-trip this April I will visit once again!It's so close to Pantheon and the city center, that you might as well give your self the pleasure of experiencing it.
Dark, but look at the ceiling. The ceiling is special, looks like a little dome, but in fact it is a painting. The rest of the church is a bit average.

a much overlooked church.. By all means, visit this church, but go in the afternoon and having seen and marvelled at the lapis lazuli colums, the baroque paintings, leave the church and go the a small door on the side and ask to see the private rooms . You will be brought along corridors, up stairs to the small apartment where the saint lived and worked. Beside here is a small chapel that on first glance seems to have dreadful guady figures, but stand inside in the middle and the whole room falls into 3 d perspective. Painted by a jesuit, this delightful chapel depicts saints peeping arounf columns and cherubs , with dangling legs on the ceiling. Go have a look.

This is prettier than the Sistine Chapel. You will also not have to wait in any lines....It is really pretty on the inside and out. You will pass it on the way to see the Pantheon, and might as well stop. The Pantheon is a waste of time.
Most impressive church so far. Make sure you don't miss to visit this church. It's not that special from the outside (but still huge) but the building is really impressive and high from the inside!

we need to know more in life for future. ok thanks but on few days i was just need to get a support letter can be sure my place is booked already to viste the church of sant'lgnazio di loyola from 5 to 9 of may that one need you to confirm by a notice a can keep with me ......thanks .
Beautiful interior. Amazing interior, and the story of the Jesuits is incredible. The piazza in front of the church has uniquely shaped buildings surrounding it.
Do my eyes deceive me?. Remarkable example of an optical trick on a massive scale. Do you believe what you see or do you see what you believe is there? Well worth visiting to see the 'false dome'.

My favorite roman church. I come here every time I go to Rome. The ceiling is among the most beautiful I've ever seen. The church as a whole is a place of great beauty.
The square in front of the church is a remarkeable piece of rococo architecture - one of the few examples of this period in Rome.
Ceiling was fantastic. It was the first church I entered when we went to ROme. I was really awestruck with the ceiling of the church
The fake dome. In the center of the church there is a dark dome which is painted to give the pespective of a concave dome, but it's flat.

A gem in Rome. Happened to visit the cathedral and never regret going in. The cathedral's ceiling was painted in such a way that it makes you think the ceiling is higher than it actually is. Another amazing thing was the dome. It was actually a painting but you won't be able to realise it until you look at it directly underneath.
Beautiful!. This church was dedicated to Ignatius of Layola, founder of the Jesuits. Though there are many churches in Rome, this one is definitely worth a visit.
Beautiful ceiling!. Be sure to check out the false dome. Look for the mark on the floor and stare at the ceiling. It's an awesome optical illusion.

A real Gem!. Before you go in, take a few minutes to admire the tiny but beautiful piazza outside the church. The piazza is laid out like a stage complete with exits to the 'wings'.Inside the church, your eye is immediately drawn to the exquisite tromp l'oeil frescoes on the ceiling which draw you heaven bound. I was sorely tempted to lie down to take it all in without getting a sore neck and feeling dizzy!Every available surface is covered is beautiful paintings and sculptures as good as in any of the other churches in a city known for outstanding churches. However, the effect is not at all over the top, just serene and spiritual.Just a few minutes walk from the crowds of the Pantheon, take time to sit down, rest your weary feet and recharge your batteries.

Interesting 3-D Ceilings. This church has some interesting art and really great 3-D painted ceilings - very unusual. The false dome, however, was not as 3-D as expected. Good place to spend an hour and it's close to the Pantheon and not far from the Trevi Fountain.
Nice mock-up. This church is a must-see! It's really beautiful and the model of the historic temple (cover of this attraction) is really impressive!
Avoid the crowds and see this site. Some of the best frescos and artwork outside the Vatican. Well worth your time. If you are visiting the Pantheon it is just a couple of blocks away. Don't miss it.

check it out!. The Church is very close to the Pantheon. There is a lot of beautiful art work done inside the Church and make sure to look up as the ceiling was beautiful.
There is no entrance fee and make sure to visit it on your way to Pantheon or trivia fountain.
Well worth a look. We popped in whilst wandering the cobbles and were truly surprised by the incredible interior. Make sure you stand on the spot marked on the floor to view the ceiling.
Peace and calm. If you are religious this was the first place you could light a candle, they offered personal tours and the price was at your discretion.

Beautiful baroque. Lovely baroque church in a city that's full of exceptional churches. Midway up the nave on the right side, you'll find a rickety pay station where for 0,50 euro you can light up the trompe l'oile dome and the frescoed ceiling.

Don't walk past... breathtaking interior.. We almost walked past. I'm so glad we didn't. There is so much to see and take in. Beauty everywhere you look. The ceiling is fantastic and the frescos tell so many stories. It's just worth taking a few moments to stand still and absorb all you can see. I am already looking forward to a return visit, I'm sure it is somewhere that every visit provides a new memory.
History. Interesting chuch for its 'false' dome and surprising interior - quite striking and not what we expected walking throught the front door.On for lovers of design.
Very Nice. One of the nicest ones I went to in Rome. Liked it very much. Top 3 in my list. The ceiling is awesome !!!
Really beautiful. A really beautiful church! The ceiling, the walls, all the details make this church a must see in Rome.
Don't walk past!. The facade is very understated. Don't walk past. We popped in by chance and the church is grander than the Cistine chapel. Truly a gem!

Beautiful church with tromp l’oeil "dome". Behind the massive baroque exterior by Carlo Maderno is a beautiful frescoed ceiling and an amazing optical illusion of a "dome," painted to resemble a three dimensional dome. The ceiling and "dome" are the work of the painter Andrea Pozzo, a Jesuit lay brother (the saint for which the church is named was the founder of the Jesuit order). The high altar is beautiful, and the church's side chapels and many sculptures are well worth a visit. Bring some small coins to light up the church ceiling, especially at night. The church stands in Piazza di Sant’Ignazio, a lovely square laid out in 1727 -- the buildings facing the church are all slightly curved, giving the piazza an unusual shape.

Favorite little church. This church was actually really cool! Stuck out in my memory from other churches (and we went to a bunch) cause of all the visual illusions in the paintings! You will think there is a large dome in this church but in fact it is a tromp l'oeil painting on the ceiling. Very fun!

a by chance visit - amazing. We just happened to pass this church on our way to the Trevi fountain, having been recommended it by a former rector of the English College here. Superb ceiling frescos and side chapels filled with bright white marble statues. Not to be missed.
Astounding. What a surprise, an austere exterior and a sumpuous interior and a choral concert to boot. A must see on any trip to Rome

Stunning Beauty!. As a product of Jesuit education, this was a must-do on my trip! Wow--it is absolutely beautiful (as are most of the churches in Rome). As another reviewer said--the ceiling is out of this world! If you have any connections to the Jesuits, and even if you don't, come by and admire this large work of art! Wow!
Worth A Visit. A magnificent church and a must place to visit while in Rome. The artworks are gorgeous and the ceiling stunning.

Very moving. I got a wonderful warm feeling from this church, there are lots of gorgeous artworks, and it felt very peaceful. The fake dome only works from the front of the church, but it's still an interesting thing to see.
the ceiling. The Ceiling! But don't neglect the fabulous library of the Jesuit university (entrance to the side street, to your left) bring your passport, or they will not let you in.
Amazing art!. We were absolutely thrilled painting, I was in many places but this church with painings is fantastic! You have to see it by yourself!
Magnificent!. This beautiful church is a close tie to Saint Peter's in my book. Magnificent painted ceilings and glorious Baroque details.

Gorgeous!. This church has gorgeous paintings and wonderful sculptures. It is definitely worth going to. When we visited there was hardly anyone there so we could see the beautiful art without fighting the crowds. Loved it!

when in Rome visit Churches!. I´m so glad we followed the tips to visit as many churches as we can when we visit Rome... Each church has something different to admire but if I had to choose I would recommend the first one we visited and that's San't Ignazio di Loyola.We were lucky this church was right next to Caravita otherwise I'm not sure if we were going to try as many churches as possible in 3 days in the city. Once you get in you can't but feel the vibe, the silence, the spiritual sense, the baroque style.Totally recommended if you're only gonna visit a couple of churches do not miss this one

Another stunning church....... One can't help but have a sense of reverence visiting here. From the floors to the ceiling, the time, the craftsmanship, one can't help but be awed. Visit as many of these as you can, you be glad you did.
Awesome frescos on the ceiling. THis place is great and not very croweded. I think the paintings are better than the Sistine Chapel and you don't have to fight the crowds.
Impressive. You will notice when you're in Rome that churches are in the main, awesome. Never miss the opportunity to pop your head in however grand or basic they may look.

A church not to be missed. Rome is full of splendid churches....you cannot see them all...you need to be selective...if you plan to pick a couple of churches to visit, this must be one of them....the painting on the ceiling is breath taking!

A Holy Place. This church is on the signposted way from the Pantheon to the Trevi Fountain, and as such is hard to miss, standing sentinel as it does on it's own small square. Others have reviewed the art I would like to approach from a different tack. We attended mass here on the Feast of the Epiphony, January 6th, traditionally the last day of Christmas. The experience was wonderful. The service was in Italian, which to our shame we do not speak, and yet the experience of mixing with locals and fellow travellers was humbling and inspiring. An enthusiastic organist played throughout the ceremony. The music and the wonderful surroundings made for a magical experience, spoiled only a little by the tourists who insisted in walking up the centre aisle during the service. I would ask people, whether believers or not, to respect that fact that such sights are sacred to many. Lovely church, convenient, and no reason not to enjoy a visit.
Astounding church. This church is free and easy elevation, the wall is three dimensional, very beautiful church, do not forget to turn on the light.
awesome. very close to pantheon it's a must see! everything on this church is just wonderful. careful not to miss it as the entrance is not as espectacular as the inside

3D paintings that seem very real; very interesting. The paintings are 3D and seem very real. It's close to the Panteon and the Trevi fountain so it's very easy to visit it. It's located in a small and nice square.

Concert of Cypress Creek Community Choir. I went to a concert held at Church of Sant'Ignazio di Loyola. It was Monday 6th January, the concert was given by Cypress Creek Community Choir from Huston Texas USA. The church was beautiful and the acoustic was very sympathetic to the beautiful choral singing. I wish you were here to enjoy this church and choir.

Free and a nice stop. Decided to visit and it was beautiful. The ceiling was beautiful, we were there at the endOf the day and it was getting dark, proabably better during the day for the natural light aspect. There was someone standing at the enterance collecting money, but there is no entrance fee, so I am pretty sure someone was trying to rip people off. Check it out of you can.
the roof!. Beautiful! Excellent trompe-l'oeil painting. And the square outside is so pretty! It's one of my favourites.

A wonderful church with a huge painted ceiling like the sistine chapel ceiling. Sant'Ignazio church is located in the city center or Rome in a beautiful square (Sant'Ignazio) located between trevi fountain, via del corso and the pantheon (so it is a must walk for every tourist). There you would see a small and delicious square in which all the front buildings build a scenery, just in front of the big white facade of the church. When you enter this baroque church, you remain breathless by the richnnes of all the chapels and the big central nave. Then you watch up at the nave ceiling and you see a 3 D painted vault that goes up in the sky ..... The images are all painted but they are so valive and vibrant that they seem sculptures...... Some visitors don't even enter in this church which is more than a museum in itself and it is free.... Everybody line up to see the sistine chapel forgetting sant'Ignazio huge painted ceiling.Also the painted dome is a surprise.... it is painted as if it was a dome but it is a fake.... there is not dome in this great church.... but just a painted dome in a flat ceiling so another great surprise.....

As good as the Vatican. Nothing can compare to the Sistine Chapel but this comes close. Must see while in Rome. Simply amazing. Was not crowded when we visited and just steps from the Hotel Albergo Cesari (recommended).
Very impressive and near the Pantheon - double hit. Not as crowded as other churches, so you can really see the art for centuries ago up clsoe and personal. WOW
Amazing architecture. Wow...this is very wonderful architecture with so many history behind the construction. You must visit it if you come to Rome. It's a MUST.

Cool paint job. The church is very ornate, and has a fake "dome" done by using perspective art to trick the eye into seeing depth on a flat ceiling. We really enjoyed the Christmas Mass there as well, even though is was in Italian, and we did not speak the language, we were welcome to attend.
Beautiful statues and frescos. Loved the ceiling frescoes of St. Loyola and the Jesuits work in the four corners of the world. The memorial statues of the two Popes are quite nice as well.
amazing marbles. the church is amazing,has the best sculptures made by marble. the entrance is free. do not miss a visit, definetely worths it.

A stunning surprise. We wandered in on a whim and were immediately mesmerised by the amazing Trompe l'oeil ceiling frescoes. This is a quiet glorious haven and a "must visit" for anyone in the area especially if they want to be wowed by a huge dome, that isn't !!

Amazing. We went here as part of a free tour but we had to go back to investigate further. The ceiling painting is amazing and would have to be the best optical illusion I have seen. The ceiling is completely flat but you would never think so!

you really need to see it. We popped in here late afternoon and a man with a clipboard gave us a little tour for free. I was waiting for a catch and there wasnt one. He even used his own money to put in the box to turn the lights on. The ceilling is like 3d, its very detailed. Seeing as this church is near the main sites and is free, you should take a look.
Try not to miss!. No crowds, fabulous location on the Roman wall and beautiful inside. Favourite church well worth the tube ride
St Ignaious Loyola. We saw this during the night tour so the church was closed, but the guide was so interesting that we went back the following day to actually walk through it. It facinating
Beautiful. Visited lots of chruches whilst in Rome, but this one was stunning. Great to sit and reflect as well as to see the gorgeous surroundings, a must see

Amazing ceiling!. I was mesmerised by the ceiling designed by Michelangelo! A great piece of artwork! Not crowded at all when I visited at about 3.30pm, only a few other tourists and therefore, the quiet and peace made the church even more awesome. Spent some quiet time sitting on the bench admiring the serene and beautiful surrounding and it really quietens my heart a lot. As it is near Christmas time, there is even a nativity display in the church. Well worth my visit!

You are in Jesuit territory here!. Sant Ignazio is a baroque pile full of the glory of the Catholic church at its Counter-Reformation height. The decoration is de rigour Roman baroque which is fine, but somewhat heavy for my taste. One interesting feature is the plaster model statue of St Ignatius that is a one to one scale model of the marble statue in St Peter's Basilica. I did pick up a good card with an image of St Ignatius.

Beautiful Example of Rome Arhcitecture. Truly stunning building, outside and in, and you will not regret taking the time to wander around the space, appreciating the detail that went into the stonework and frescos that are on show. A Grand Baroque Church. The Chiesa Sant 'Ignazio in Rome is dedicated to Ignazio of Loyola, founder of the Jesuit order. It is built in the no-holds-barred gold-on-gold Baroque style. Check hours during summer months, as the church may close earlier in August (for holidays). Anywhere else in the world, the Sant' Ignazio would be mobbed with worshippers and tourists. It is indicative of the myriad splendors of Rome that this church is free to the public and usually sparsely visited, even at the height of tourist season. The main reason to visit is to see the awe-inspiring tromp-l'oeil frescoes in the ceiling, painted by Andrea Pozzo in response to the Baciccia frescoes at the Basilica Il Gesu. The frescoes depict the optical illusion of saints and angels ascending to the sky alongside marble columns. These three-dimensional illusions were painted onto shallow domed ceilings---an artistic trick when architectural budgets were constrained. The saints ascend along painted marble columns to heaven. Animals and people from around the world are depicted: jaguars, horses, crocodiles. They are enormous and the message is unmistakable: Christ tames all. The domed ceiling at the nave can be illuminated for 0.50 Euro (the coin). There is also a marvelous and beautiful model near the entrance of the church of various ecclesiastical buildings around the globe. Truly a beauty. You will not be disappointed.

Jesuit Church. I am sure this church has been getting added attention since the new Pope Francis is a Jesuit. This is a wonderful church to visit while close by at the Pantheon. Beautiful. This church leaves you speachless. Found it on the way to the Pantheon and was absolutely amazed. Spend time to see the ceiling and all the details.

unexpected find. Beautiful frescoes and wonderful ceiling paintings - very quiet and peaceful. We found this just by chance as we passed on the way to the Trevi fountain and it was well worh opening the door.

All so beautiful. The churches in Rome are all so beautiful, that they start to run together in one's memory. Fascinating. Like a hidden gem. Spectacular inside and very interesting. Just arround the corner from the Hotel Albergo Cesari. Worth a visit

Epic ceiling. Far too many visitors come to Rome, wander past this spot and never stop - and what a shame that is! Rome has so many Church domes but only one church-dome-knock-off. It's well worth a visit if you're in the area.
Beautiful. What a wonderful church. The frescoes inside by Andrea Pozzo are stunning and I have a sore neck from looking up!
Unbelievable ceiling.. Go for the ceiling. It will absolutely blow your mind. It is not too big, and won't take too long. Don't miss this. I promise you won't regret it.

An absolute must see church in the city of a thousand churches!!!. This church is extremely beautiful - in a sense even more so than St. Peters. Beautiful Church. Beautiful church and much bigger and grander than I had imagined it might be. There was a performance/choir later in the evening on the day we visited that I wish we could have gone back for. The Piazza that church is in is small and quaint and delightful. Good restaurant across from the church - where we enjoyed a tasty, relaxing lunch -and of course, great people watching. Very enjoyable afternoon venture.
INCLUDE THIS ONE ON THE TOUR. we arrived to this church by accident, however we were wondered by it frescoes, COMPLETELY AMAZING!!! nothing to envy from other more famous chapells and basilicas
Definitely worth a visit. Wonderful church full of baroque masterpieces - the ceiling - the sculptures no entrance fee and able to take photos

A masterpiece of "art in perspective".. The Church of Saint Ignatius of Loyola (Chiesa di Sant 'Ignazio di Loyola a Campo Marzio) has one of the most beautiful interiors throughout Italy. With its construction started in 1626 and finished 25 years later, is dedicated to the founder of the Jesuit order. A jesuit brother, Andrea Pozzo, was invited to paint the frescoes on the ceiling of the nave and created a true masterpiece that leaves visitors speechless with so much beauty. Based on the text of Luke, dealing with subjects about fire and light, observers have the feeling that the figures are flying in the open sky, or even falling over them. In the center of the church, there is a circle of marble on the floor, from where you have a better perspective and where the illusion caused by the images, become almost real. Four continents are represented, besides himself Ignacio de Loyola being received by Christ and the Virgin Mary in paradise. This church is not the best known in Rome, but to aficionados for good art is a must visit.

Try to include this Church on your "Must See" list.. So glad we made it to see this Church. The artwork is amazing and the artist made the figures look like they are coming out of the picture. Really a hidden gem.
Magnificent. Magnificent and grand... One of the more beautiful churches in Rome. No entrance fees and they allow photography

excellent underrated church. Loved this small quaint church with the wonderful ceiling painted by carveggio, definitely could see the 3 d effect and appreciate the effort,despite not being an ardent art lover,must see,entry was free,addln bonus:)

Stunning ceiling painting. It is a must in Rome to go and see this church. It is not bigger nor more beautiful than many others, but the key attraction is the painting on the ceiling. It is a trompe l'oeil depicting the skies opening up allowing Saint Ignatius to ascend into Heaven, being welcomed to Jesus and Virgin Mary. The ceiling is actually a barrel-shaped one, but the fresco (by Pozzo) gives the impression of a multitude of columns and vaults on top of each other, above which the saints and angels hover among the clouds.A marble disc in the floor mark the exact point from where the fresco should be watched. Immediately you move away from here, some of the columns will start leaning to one side. If watching from one of the corners of the nave, the entire perspective becomes totally false.There is a second fresco in the church, giving the impression of being a dome. But it is very dark and needs renovation. It is by no means as impressive as the main one. The location of the church is very central in Rome. It is very close to ther Pantheon in the direction of the Trevi Fountain.

Above-average trompe l'oeil ceiling art. This building is historically interesting as the principal church honoring the founder of the Jesuit Order, but the principal attraction for us was the trompe l'oeil work on the ceiling.

Beautiful ceiling, lovely church. This is a beautiful church, one of the best we visited, and is tucked away in a lovely part of the city, between the Trevi fountain and the Pantheon. If you are going from one to the other (and you should!) it is well worth a visit. Very quiet and peaceful
Fantastic!!!. Fantastic trompe l'oeil ceiling, well worth a visit. A beautiful church close to the Pantheon so you can do two brilliant sites in no time at all.
Concert venue. Our choir sang here for our opening concert. The space is both physically and aurally appealing. There's only a couple toilets, so go beforehand!
Simply beautiful!. I enetered this church having no idea what was inside and I was delighted that I did. This church is outstanding and is one not to miss.

Wow factor. Not having time to visit Cistine Chapel or St Peters I poked my head around some unassuming church doors to find something beyond belief. Just look at that ceiling. Overall, the inside of the church is very pretty. The fresco on the ceiling by the entrance is amazing. You really get the effect that there is no ceiling and all the characters in the painting are floating above you.

Fake dome!. This church is interesting because instead of a dome, they have hung a canvas over the would-be dome's opening and have painting it to look like a dome!

HD baroque art that even kids will love. San Ignazio has so many things to offer the visitor, but the two I take young people to see (especially if it's a sunny day) are the ceiling and the dome. The HD/3D ceiling is stunning, with characters leaping everywhere and so much movement it's hard not to get dizzy. After craning their necks for a few minutes, I then take visitors to see the dome. Visitors look up at the dome and say "so what"? The "so what" in this case is that the dome is fake. It's an optical illusion drawn very carefully by the artist. Even after telling visitors this, they take a while to get their eyes not to lie to them. That's the fun.As I said, there is so much more to this counter reformation masterpiece, but for the casual and time constrained visitor, this is enough.

Just as good as the Sistine, and it's free!. If you can't make it to the Sistine, without a doubt, this is your best substitute! I walked into this church and my draw literally dropped, it's amazing! The fresco definitely plays well to le tromp d'oiel, (trick of the eye). The decoration is extravagant and just has this 'feel' to it similar to the Sistine. Would highly highly recommend to all.

Sant'Ignazio Di Loyola. Well worth a visit. One wonders how much exploitation is needed for a church to display so much gold and precious stones but that aside the illusionistic cupola was just amazing

Go for the "dome"!. So, I must have visited this church a few times, before I really noticed its magnificence! There are hundreds of beautiful churches in Rome, that this one is especially unique. From the outside, it doesn't look like much, but from the inside it is spectacular! The ceiling frescoes have so much depth and clarity. The figures look like they are actually projecting off of the ceiling. But the most amazing part of the church is how they expanded limited space. You will notice that the church looks much bigger inside than it does from the outside. And this is all due to optical illusions, the trompe l'oeil, effect. The dome, from the point of entrance to the center of the church looks very believable. It isn't until you are standing directly under it, when you notice something is off. It is an illusion painted on a flat ceiling. NO dome at all! It is even more amazing to think about how the effect must have been hundreds of years ago, with no artificial lighting. And to think how the calculations of perspective must be right on to attain such an effect. After visiting this church, you will be more inclined to really "look" at your surroundings. You might start seeing the entire city from a different angle...

Awesome Cathedral. This is a most beautiful Church. The setting on the street made it most imposing and impressive. Inside the ceilings were breathtaking. Incredible ceiling.. This is a beautiful church but its real distinguishing feature is its ceiling executed by Andrea Pozzo who was a Jesuit monk based there. It is almost impossible to believe that the ceiling is actually flat. The windows which let in sunlight are - obviously - real but everything above is a trick created by skillful use of perspective. He has painted in another layer of windows, columns and archways with the illusion of incredible space and light. Exuberant angels, saints and cherubs accompany St Ignatius as he is bathed in celestial light and transported to heaven.Pozzo has also painted a false dome which entirely fools the eye until you move from the designated point on the floor and the perspective shifts to reveal this to be another illusion. It is incredibly difficult to imagine how he envisioned and executed this with such skill. In its own way it is as amazing as the ceiling in the Sistine Chapel.

This church is spectacular!. After St. Peter's Basilica and the Pantheon, this is the most beautiful church I have ever seen! Look for the "domed" ceiling that isn't really a dome but a fresco painting made to trick the eye to thinking it's a dome!

Beautiful. We walked past this church a few times on our way to the trevi fountain. One day we decided to call in.Absolutely beautiful and breath taking. Not busy or full or tourists, like a quiet haven in the hustle and bustle of central Rome.

Beautiful Church. We stayed very close to this church and visited on more than one occasion. I think this was one of the most beautiful churches in Rome. I would definitely recommend a stop if you are there when the church is open.

Calm. When you visit to this church you are entering an oasis of calm in the centre of this city. Not to be missed! The church with the fake dome.. As Rick Steve's Guidebook says, 'this church is a riot of Baroque illusions.' Its a favorite church in Rome - free, of course. Beautiful church, definitely worth seeing. This church was not too far from the Pantheon if I remember correctly and the inside is so beautiful, worth a look. Intricate decor inside, absolutely stunning.

beautiful church. This church is hidden on Piazza Nouvona and contains works of Michaelangelo. It is definitely worth a visit.
Gorgeous,thought provoking!. So glad to have come here whilst hitting some of the usual attractions in Rome. Absolutely beautiful in so very many ways. See for yourself.

Over the Top Baroque!. Went there twice. It was in the evening the first time we went, couldn't see the artwork on the ceiling, but we encountered a beautiful rehearsal for a concert. Behind the facade. This church like in many in Rome is a wonderful surprise. well worth a visit and they also frequently host free evening concerts from visiting choirs. We were enjoyed a choral ensemble from South Carolina giving a wonderful selection of Christmas music-excellent!

Off the Beaten Path Gorious Church. I didn't read about this church in any of the tourist books I perused before our trip to Rome, but man was I happy my wife and I stopped in here. Simply gorgeous. Impressive frescoes on the ceiling. The photos of the ceiling say it all... Keep in mind that the ceiling is no higher than the top of the windows!
