Absolutely Stunning. We went into this church out of pure luck. It's fair I was absolutely blown away. We spent a lot of our time hunting out more churches, but none really compared to the initial shock of this amazing place. The artwork is amazing, it is so peaceful and unlike anything that we have in Britain. Even if you are not religious, go to be amazed. I had tears in my eyes.
Superb 3-D paintings on the ceiling. This church was well worth the stop because of the 3-D illusion of the paintings on the ceiling, and several marble sculptures.
Beautiful church !!. Beautiful painted vault with perspective!! The circle on the floor shows you where to stand to admire it.
lovely concert. We were there on All Saints Day and there was an orchestra and choir performing. All were welcomed into this absolutely wonderful church.

Read up before you go. My guidebook doesn't have much on this church but I wish I had done more research before we went. The frescoes are truly beautiful. The church's very large size gives the ceiling space to really envelop you. The infornpmation provided inside the church about the various chapels was minimal, I thought, but they were each interesting, specially the ones that seemed yet-to-be-finished. You could spend an hour in here easily. We plan to go back.

Beautiful frescos. This is not to be missed! The frescos are glorious and the guide was very informative. Definitely put this one on your list. Do a bit of studying about Loyola before you go. It will enhance your visit.
Magnificent!. A high baroque Jesuit large church between the Pantheon and Il Gesu. Splendid paintings -- site of the famous illusionist frescoes -- particularly in the dome. Also, a concert venue.
Absolutely amazing ceilings!. this church may not be on the top of everyone's must see list but it should be. The ceilings are just amazing.

Beautiful church. Definitely worth a visit. Its free, so pop in and check it out. Well recommended. We particularly liked the paintings and decorative art. There is a model replica with all the cathedrals from all over the world. Beautiful church!

A Trompe l'Oeil Gem!. Came upon this church entirely by accident...we went in only because we saw tourists emerging with guide books open and figured there had to be something special inside. The church is a gem and gives you a sense of having discovered something all on your own, even if it is rather well-known. The trompe l'oeil ceiling with its convincing--yet false--dome provides homage to the Renaissance through its expertly rendered perspective and realism. By the way, even in the dark, you can still get a sense of the visual trickery!

Look Up. This church has a fascinating history -- read about it or find a guide (we hired the outstanding guide, Marta Marsili, martamarsili@hotmail). And by all means, look up at the ceiling and ponder the brilliance of the "false" dome. Look at it from all angles -- the mathematics of it will appeal to the analytics and the beauty will appeal to everyone. And find the Caravaggio painting to appreciate his understanding of light and shade, and read about his tumultuous life!

Optical illusion!. Not only it was one of the most remarkable churches we've visited in Rome, but thanks to our guide Stefano we realized it was also one of the most quizical. We were there around 7pm (closing time) it was somewhat spooky however pay attention to the dome. The truth is - there is no dome but the optical illusion of the artist instead.

Look up!. An important church with stunning ceilings. Note the continuation of the pillars and arches through the ceiling, and the false dome. An interesting history, also. For church buffs this is a must.

Look up at the ceiling. This beautiful church has a bit of an optical illusion. The ceiling looks curved but the further you walk into the church you find the ceiling is flat. So many churches in Rome, this is a must to visit for the artwork and also the serenity as you sit and admire it all
Family of four. Very interesting piece of art and state of conservation, and fantastic surroundings. Nice to visit when dark
Worth it for the model alone. Have a look at the amazing model of the dome made in wood and be amazed at the detail usually only seen by the birds.
Cool ceiling. The pained ceiling is amazing, you have to study it hard to work out which bits are flat and which really stick out.

Trick painted ceiling. A gentleman from he church wanders around and lets the visitors know of all the things they should see. A very nice touch. Find the spot on the floor to see the fake domed ceiling.

Beautiful Church. Once you start seeing one church in Rome they are all so beautiful it is hard to distinguish one from another...we stepped in here just to see and did not stay long and was not disappointed.

A daily, short, sound and light spectacle!. The fifteen minute sound and light show with the saint - resplendent - appearing at the end to a full-throat chorus and splendid organ acoustics is a must-see!!

Beautiful Church. This church was well worth the visit, but if you are interested in the Jesuits, I would highly suggest the Church of Gesu (the head church), as it is further off the tourist track and you can see the place where Saint Ignatius lived his last days next door.

Hidden Gem. We stumbled upon this attraction in errorVery impressed with the art and other features. The stand out display was a model that featured religious buildings surrounding a main building. Such detailThe children were not as impressed but it had been a long dayDo try and find this place. It costs nothing to enter but like many of the religious buildings I would make sure the respectful attire is worn. My daughter felt very uncomfortable in shorts and left. That is not the fault of the place, it was ours. Worth noting though

Mind-blowing.. The Chiesa del Gesu has always been my favorite church in Rome: it's the most spectacular and sublime demonstration of Baroque art you'll ever see. But it now has a rival for my affections! Sant'Ignazio blew. My. Mind. I've never seen anything like it. Google-image-search it and you'll see what I mean. Bring a camera that can do a high ISO like 3200+ -- your pictures will draw raves from family and friends.
One of the best in Rome. The illusion paintings on the ceiling are incredible. The side alters have incredible artifacts and the architecture is induring.

Excellent paintings. This was one of my favourite places we visited in Rome. There's so many lovely buildings in Rome it may not seem anything extraordinary from the outside but step inside and gaze upwards. The ceiling depicts St. Ignazious' ascension into heaven. The ceiling looks almost 3D and like its really going up and up towards heaven when you stand right in the middle of the front part of the church. Gaze towards the altar and you'll notice an impressive dome you didn't notice from outside. Step right up underneath the dome and look again. This place is brilliant and because its not as crowded as the pantheon, Sistine chapel, etc. it still feels like a nice quiet peaceful chapel where you can have a prayer in beautiful surroundings which made it more special to me.

Amazing Trompe l'oil frescos. We wandered into this church by accident and it was by far our favorite of the visit. The frescos on the ceiling seemed to be hanging over the marble arches - the colors were so vibrant!
Amazing. Surprising that this beautiful church was barely even marked on our walking tour--just a spot between the Trevi Fountain and the Pantheon. It was lovely.

Tromp L'oieul.. This church is one of the Jesuit churches in Rome. It is very baroque in decoration, with the highlight being a false dome, best viewed on the aisle right by the barricade. Pay for the lights to be turned on. Other decor includes a statue tromping on some poor guy, whom I assume is a Protestant. A nice diversion in the Pantheon neighborhood.
another must see church near the pantheon. The trompe l'oiel ceilings are a marvel - not to be missed. The arches "become" the ceiling - is this the start of surrealistic style??

Beautiful Little Church. Most beautiful ceiling frescoes in this church close to the Pantheon that is recommended in the current Rick Steeves book. Just a few minutes away from the Pantheon and recommend you see if in the are.
BEAUTIFUL. The Mass together with the liturgies introducing the Year of Faith were solemn and inspirational. Nostalgic.
Beautiful. Wow! We found this church to be stunning. The ceiling is the highlight. Well worth the stop. We visited many churches during our visit and this was one of the most original designs.

Put it on your list!. I'm so glad I put this church on my to-see list thanks to Tripadvisor...truly was worth visiting. The trompe l'oiel ceilings were magnificent and the false cupolla is something to be witnessed in person! My husband wouldn't believe me at first until we moved from the "ideal viewing spot" marked on the floor to one of the side aisles...then he was blown away. As with any church in Rome, don't forget to have something to cover your shoulders (and no short shorts!) as there was someone checking the day we were there (early October).
Fabulous. Be sure to check out the ceiling. It is a wonderful example of troupe l'oiel. It is one of the best in the world in fact.

Impressive Baraque Illusions!. This church is dedicated to Ignatius of Loyola, the founder of the Jesuit order. Outside, the church faces the headquarters of the Carabinieri police force. You may get one or two beggars at the entrance asking for donations.Entrance is free. Inside,it has a magnificent large colourful ceiling fresco. Simply beautiful! This illusion fools the eye into thinking that it is an extension of the church architecture. Find a seat to admire the beauty. Also, the fake dome is an amazing illusion. If we didn't read about it beforehand, we would have been fooled. Some religious articles and postcards are sold near the entrance, but it opens late.The church is easily accessible on foot from the Pantheon.

Beautiful !!. Situated on a lovely plaza between the Pantheon and Trevi Fountain. The church was an unxpected surprise.No cost to enter, but beware the woman outside asking for money, or "donations". We were sitting on the church steps, and saw her dig into her basket of money and give to her co-hort, who returned shortly with food and beer !!!

reviews are correct. reviews are correct it is a Gem, we discovered this place because of reviews on here and we was lucky enough to arrive when a service of sorts was taking place, the church was alive with singing and sermons, the priests dressed in Red gowns, some in white ones, spectacular! very decorative as you would expect but a must see!

A must see church. I can only agree with the many great reviews. The fake dome is amazing. Dont miss it. Word of warning -you get fake collectors stood outside claiming to collect for the church!. They dont it goes in their pocket we watched one!. Leave any donation inside in the collection box.

Awesome 3-D Trompe l'oeil Ceiling. Rome abounds in awesome, masterful painted ceilings ... and this is one of them. It's just a couple of blocks from the Palazzo Doria Pamphili, so you can see both on the same outing.

very impressive church. Unbelievable 3 dimensional illusion. We were speechless and awed by its effect and beauty. For us it was an accidental visit and unexpectedness played a big role. We spent almost 2 hours there.

dome. You need really to walk in and don't look up, go to the centre and then look at the top, the dome will look like a real dome, and if you then move to any other side you will see that looks only like a paint,but really suggestive! One of our favourites!

Awesome. This fantastic building has a wonderful silver altar, and the ceiling is done in the Trompe l'oieiul fashion. Take small coins with you so that you can light up dark chapels.Outside id Bernini's Elephant, he's lovely

Breathtakingly beautiful. All the positive reviews of this church are on square on the mark. This is easily one of the most beautiful and impressive sights in all of Rome. Not to be missed. It's also pleasantly close and accessible from the Pantheon and Piazza Navona. The ceiling frescos are absolutely incredible and the Andrea Pozzo illusionary dome is a marvel; if you haven't been alerted to the fact that there really is no dome, you would not believe it!
Amazing!. Make sure you check out the fake dome painted in the center of the ceiling. Amazing art everywhere, and not crowded when we went. Stunning!

Found by accident. Came across this church by accident while walking to see the pantheon, we went in and im so glad we did its so ornate an beautiful, unfortunately it did ruin my trip to St Peters basilica I thought this was far nicer I would recommend that you take the time and stop to have a look as it is not as busy with tourists

The best Church in Rome. Came across this Church by accident. if you like Churches (or even if you don't) this is one of the best I have ever seen. Do yourself a favour and visit. Trying to describe it would be an injustice!
a gem. We are not religious but these churches make you really appreciative of the artistry and craftmanship involved

Almost missed this one!. We almost walked past this church without noticing it! Says a lot for our attention, but we made up for it and loved the interior. At times we were almost " churched" out in Rome but making the decision to look at one more often paid off with a lovely suprise.The ceiling frescoes are beautiful works of art and so clever in this Jesuit masterpiece. A church to be enjoyed. The influence of the church around the world is portrayed in a nearby niche with a novel model created in wood. Don't miss this one!
Beautiful. This is a very large and beautiful church. One of the few churches where the didn't seem to mind if you took many photos.

Wow!!. As you walk through Rome, it is hard to even pay attention to where and what you are walking into there's so much to see. Everywhere you turn there is a historical building or a monument or a church. I've been to so many churches that I almost missed this one. It was a very deceiving building as from the outside you couldn't tell the sheer size of this gorgeous church!! It is a true beauty and a must see! When in Rome, do as the Romans do...go to Church. All of them. :)

So nondescript outside, but absolutely beautiful inside. Just walking in the piazza, we went inside this church. The beautiful baroque interior takes your breath away. You look up and there are so many different stories going on.

The Pozzo Ceiling is a Must See!. As you walk in this church try to find the middle of the hall and walk within the narrow path looking up. This is the way the Jesuit brother Andrea Pozzo, designed his fresco ceiling to be seen. It is a wonderful marvel of perspective, which only works when you remain on the central path. The dome especially needs to be appreciated from this perspective. Once you deviate off the path the perfect symmetry distorts. The dome truly looks real until you move off the line. Brother Pozzo, was not merely a great artist his painting was designed to serve a spiritual message: it is only when you remain on the straight path that you really see things as they are. Stray off and your perspective becomes distorted!

Baroque Theatricality in Rome. Sant'Ignazio is a very good example of Baroque architecture in Rome and the Trompe l'oeil ceiling is splendid, one of the best in the city. What also helps to set the church apart is the piazza the opens in front of it. The concave façades of the buildings opposite funnel traffic from two streets forming a dramatic baroque composition that recalls Palladio's Teatro Olimpico in Vicenza. The façade of the Church completes the composition. Like the piazza and church of Santa Maria della Pace, this is one of those little unexpected surprises that makes a visit to Rome so much fun

False dome. Pozzo was a mathmetician and a holy man who said he listened to God when he worked in Sant'Ignazio. The church has the typical gold, chapels, carsophagi, but nowhere have I seen the illusionary dome. You really believe it is curved. There is also a plastic replica of the dome Pozzo intended to build located in the back of the church.
killaloe group. there a lot of steps up to this church but when in there it is a lovely church it is one of the nicest churches in rome

A beautiful discovery!. This is a delightful Church with ornate and detailed frescos on the ceiling. This a Church founded by the Jesuits with a number of individual altars along the sides and front of the Church.This Church was not included in the guidebooks but was recommended to us by the manager of our B&B. It is not to be missed and is very close to The Pantheon so you can visit when in that area.

Hands down our favorite church visited in Rome outside of St Peter's at the Vatican. We really loved this old church. We took tons of great photos and there were surprisingly few tourists inside. If you want to avoid the crowds at The Pantheon and St Peter's and enjoy a peaceful, beautiful church that you can spend a good 1-2 hours exploring, photographing, and just meditating in, this is the place to go. The frescoes, sculptures, and artwork were the best we saw (in our opinion) outside of St. Peter's. Not too far a walk from The Pantheon or really anywhere you might stay in Centro Storico.

The paintings are just great. You should go because of the paintings within this church. They are beautiful. As in many other places in Rome it doesn't matter your religious faith you will enjoy the art in the building

The Jesuit Church. St Peter's and the Vatican Museum were so crowded that they lost their appeal for me. The Church of Sant'Ignazio Di Loyal was just magnificent. The altars, frescos and paintings were all beautiful. The church was quiet and you could take your time and enjoy this holy place. A beautiful church to visit in Rome
A beautiful church. A fantastic church, full of art and sculptures with many chapels. The ceiling is amazing and would recommend this as a church to definitely visit.

Almost as good as the Sistine Chapel!. We walked from our hotel to the king of Baroque churches called St. Ignacio, the Romans call this the 3D church because the artist Pozzo painted a fake dome which looks very much like a dome if you are standing in the proper place to see it. Its very cool, moving through the church you see it become distorted and even then it is something to behold. As you enter the church you see it in the center of the main building and as you approach it, it becomes more and more visible as a dome. You have to stand in the proper place to really see it, look at the floors for a clue as to where to stand. This church is painted very much like the Sistine Chapel with biblical scenes rising up the walls and onto the roof of the church. Don't forget to turn on the lights of the dome, they really illuminate it well and it only costs one euro. Beware of beggars, and do not pay them if they tell you there is charges to see the church, all churches in Rome are free.

stunning - a jewel. it is free. the colors are amazing. the ceiling is a wonderful piece of art. the altar is one of a kind. there are sometimes concerts. no reason not to go in. amazing church. crazy.

You must see this church!. I happened on to this church and was pleasantly surprised! Being a teacher in a Jesuit school, it was wonderful to be able to see this church. I did not make it to the GESU church in ROME, but I am not disappointed after visiting St. Ignatius.

Great Jesuit church. It's located on the tourist "hike" between the Pantheon and the Trevi Fountain, so it gets a lot of traffic. The highlight of the church is the fabulous frescoes on the ceiling. Not quite the Sistine Chapel, but amazing.

A visual and spiritual gem hidden from tourists and guide books.. After leaving the Pantheon we stumbled accross this after noting a few people going in free of charge. We entered with the understanding if we do not like it then we will leave.From the momment I stepped through the door I was amazed. The ceiling contains a Fresco which shows Saint Ignazio ascending to heaven. The special feature of this is the perspective. The painting has been put onto the building so make it appear as if the church ceiling is a portal to paradise. The paint uses the beams and columns in the corner of the room to its advantage and its a wonder how angels and characters can cover more than one surface and still maintain their 3D effect.There are other sections to this but I cannot explain them well enough, I would strongly recommend this to anyone in Rome; for me it rivaled the Sistene Chapel. Have a read on Wikipedia for some background infomation.

You walk by it for days and need to go... We stay near the Pantheon several times in our visits back from our home in ITaly. We pass this beautiful building several times but never went in until this last visit. It is like an envelope when you go in.. It seems very small but its very large and has magnificent domes, naves and fresco's throughout.
Stunning Church. This is an absolutely stunning Church with painted Dome. You will be transfixed at the beauty! Well worth a visit.

Great Ceiling and organ. We heard a service and an organ recital at St Ignatius. These were beautiful. The church is large and many wonderful paintings on the ceiling which show the parts of the world covered by the Jesuit priests.
It is amazing place. I loved this church. the paints are very beautful. Inside the church there is a St Luigi Gonzaga tomb's. Great place.
A must. Do your research and visit this beautiful church with camera in hand. Then, sit back, and absorb. An absolute stand-out.

An absolute gem!. A very fascinating church in the city of churches and basilica. We went to the church as a part of the New Rome Free Tour. The ceiling is in classic baroque style and has a bunch of illusions by Pozza brilliantly hidden from the casual observer. No spoilers in this review but definitely add this church to your itinerary.

Angels flying out from the ceiling!. Guide books cannot tell you the illusions on the ceiling of this church. There's a yellow dot on the floor where you'll see the effect to the max. This is the second church I took my family to see in ROme (first was the Pantheon). The jaws just dropped.

What a trip (as in whoaaa that thing psyched me out!). This is a must see in Rome. As one of the hidden gens, it is fantastically designed. You will see optical illusions on the ceiling of all sorts and the best part is that it is FREE. Just make sure you get in there before they close (i think its around 630pm). The churches allow you to take photos but you need to take your hat off and ladies need to be well covered.
Beautiful Art. Exceptionally painted fresco ceiling and other art. Definitely worth a visit while you're near the Pantheon.

Exceptional Ceiling Art. The fresco on the ceiling of this church is truly amazing. Though a visit to this church by a protestant (aka heretics to the founder) is bittersweet, it is still worth visiting.

Filled with optical illusions. Stand on the gold disk in the floor about 20 from the front door. Look up at the cupola toward the front of the church. Then don't peek! Walk to the apse until you are directly under the cupola, then look up. ???? When the church was built in the 1600's, Andrea Pozzo, a Jesuit monk, worked with mathematicians to create many optical illusions throughout the church. The frescoed ceiling is gorgeous and depicts the continents known at that time. 2 are missing. The lapis lazuli sarcophagi, the baroque columns, the multi-colored marbles, make this a worthy visit. Don't go between 12:30 and 3:30 - the church is closed during that time.

a warm recomendation. A beautiful uncrowned church with amazing ceiling, which resembled Sistine chapel just without the crowd. We have stumbled upon this jewel on our way from Pantheon, and it left us looking for words. Outside of this church did not leave a impression on us, but as the saying goes never judge a book by its covers. It is located on a insignificant mini square opposite to a nice looking building, because of which we have actually stopped. This church is full of statues and other works of art, but its sealing left us with our mouth open. All in all a beautiful find in which one can really enjoy due to the lack of the crowd and the feeling that you are free to spend the whole day there.

stumbled upon it my 10th visit to Rome. Just when I thought I had seen too many churches, we stumble upon this one...a warm, stunning feeling came over me...maybe because it seems that everything in the US that is Catholic references St. Ignatius, maybe it was the prominent statue of St.Anthony (my favorite). Lovely church.

Favorite of all my churches in Roma. Here is a church that you do not see as many tourist at and its tucked away where it looks lot smaller from the outside then we you enter. It is magnificient!! The reds and the fresco's are stunning... It is just like opening a closest and thinking you would find nothing and you open the door to this church and its just magical.. A beautiful place to visit.

Stunning. I was glad to see this church made the list when there are so many others to compete for a visit. Often one frequently hears about the Gesu church, but as far as Jesuit-themed counter reformation temples go, this one is stunningly beautiful too. I came here during a concert and got to see the place lit up at night. The paintings over the altar and on the ceiling (which includes an interesting geography lesson so to speak) are what really set this place apart for me and others I'm sure. If you're in the area, I think stopping by for a few minutes would definitely be a worthwhile idea.

I Was Prepared and Still Got "Taken". Our hotel clerk had recommended seeing more of the churches in Rome than just St. Peter's and the Pantheon, and we're so glad he did. He even showed us Internet photos of them and had prepared us for the magical dome inside Sant'Ignatio. When we walked down the nave however, I still thought I was looking at the real deal- until I walked down to the altar. What a whimsical surprise! And no tickets or long lines to enter, either!

Hidden Gem. An easy walk halfway between the Pantheon and Trevi fountain, this beautiful church is cool and quiet in a city of crowded churches that almost seem like tourist traps. The beautiful paintings everywhere, and rich red marble had me sitting down to take it all in. There is no fee and no one trying to hawk scarves telling visitors they weren't dressed properly, which we encountered at every other religious site. (We did dress respectfully with covered knees and shoulders at all religious places.) It is also free!

Trompe L'euil. Look up! And you see it, and see it again, and again. Is it painted? Or real? Take a few minutes of the busy streets of Rome and sit on one of the church benches and just let your mind relax a bit. The cupola and the roof is painted with the technique Trompe L'euil which is designed to trick your eye. And, don't forget to put 50 cents in the little black box on the right, and you light up the cupola for a few minutes.

A City of Unbelievable Churches. Most people that have been to Rome say spend time to stick you head in the churches and not just St. Peter's. I agree wholeheartedly. This was another unbelievable church with treasures and internal architecture you could not imagine.
totally worth a visit. some of the most impressive use of perspective in the ceiling frescos that we saw in Rome. Quiet and cool, and a real surprise.
Beautiful church. This church is beautiful and worth taking the time to see.
Lovely church. Not far from the Trevi fountain and Pantheon, so was very handy when sightseeing on foot. Huge and great artwork inside. Worth a look if you're in the area.
Look up. can spend hours looking at the ceiling: the frescos are incredible!

Monte Casino. I visited the Church of St Ignatius Loyola at Monte Casino on my way to Rome. Set on top of a very steep hill with a very winding road to it. The church was beautiful and the views were spectacular although sad to see the cemeteries surrounding it from WWII
Hidden gem. We stumbled upon Sant'Ignazio and what a wonderful surprise. Another incredible ceiling and much more in marble reliefs and murals

Hidden gem!. This church is near the Pantheon, but hard to find. Situated in its own piazza, which is lovely. The church has a fake dome and a trompe l'loeil ceiling inside. I have been there many times and think how cool it is with each visit.
Astonishing frescoes on the vault. Look above and the perspective effect of the fake painted dome inside, just another piece of art

My favorite new find in Rome.. There are so many churches in Rome that they all seem to blend together. NOT this gorgeous, peaceful respite from the crunch of the world outside. I was so moved by the sanctity and beauty of this place that I wept. If you go to NO other church in Rome, go to this one. It's very close to the Pantheon.
Wonderful Church. This is a fabulous little Church on the way to the Pantheon. It is well worth a visit.

Unexpected delight.. We weren't intending to visit this cathedral but as we were sauntering by, we decided to drop in to see what it had to offer. Well, it had eye-popping art and architecture to offer and we felt as though Rome had given us an unexpected gift just seeing it.

While looking for the Pantheon... ..we stumbled on this church, and what an amazing surprise it was! Inside is beautiful, and well worth a stop. Organist was playing a pipe organ while we were there in the late afternoon, and the whole atmosphere was one of awe; it was hard to know where to put your eyes, there was so much to look at. We sat in one of the pews and just gazed up after awhile. No charge to visit this church; yet another marvel in Rome.

Perspective, Perspective, Perspective. Stand in the middle of the back of the church and look up and see an excellent example of perspective. One of my favorite free places in Rome. I also enjoy the piazza on which it sits--it's so perfect that it reminds me of a movie set. Typically Italian. The light in the morning gives it the best cast.
Fantastic. We had a tour guide who brought us here. The frescoes are unbelievable; it's a beautiful church, very memorable, and pleasant area to have lunch afterward.

Amazing Frescoes. We stumbled into this church by accident while looking for the Pantheon and were greeted by this increibly well-painted church! So typically Italian and so cool we sat in there and explore it for nearly an hour!
A treat!. We stumbled onto this beautiful place by accident, walking past, saw the open door, decided to 'take a peek'. This is simply not to be missed.

Hidden Gem. After you go to the 4 Patriarchal Basilicas, this is a must see. The artwork inside is amazing. This Basilica is very near the Pantheon and Piazza Navonna. If you aren't careful, you will pass right by. The outside, while elegant, does not foreshadow the beauty that is inside. If you have ever attended Catholic Schools this is a must. St Aloyisus Gonzaga and St Robert Bellarmine rest here. The remains St Robert Bellarmine can be viewed.
Lovely. Lovely church dedicated to Ignatius of Loyola, the founder of the Jesuit order. Superb dome and a huge statue of St. Ignatius.
One of my favorite churches in Rome.. it is beautiful and breathtaking. close to the Pantheon and should not be missed.

We stumbled into it.. I'm embarrassed to say this, but we needed to find a bathroom and saw people walking in there, but had no idea what it was. Following the crowd, we walked into this absolutely beautiful church. It was so unexpected. We were so happy we stumbled in there!

The best mid-town church. My personal favorite church in the center of Rome. The roof of this church is beyond awesome and presumably better than the Jesu. The effort of the journey is very small to make and more than worth about anything in Rome!
Spectacular. I agree with previous reviews for this church it is a breathtakingly beautiful place to visit.
Accidental discovery.. The most wonderful surprise of our trip to Rome, we just stumbled upon it and it was just breathtaking.
Amazing. This is definitely a must-see. Not far from the Pantheon and from Piazza Navona. Magnificent church, especially the murals on the ceiling.

Much more beautiful than the Sistine Chapel. This church is a must see. The ceiling is beautiful,the characters really do appear to be 3d - quite mesmerising....I agree with previous posts this us a far more special find than the Sistine Chapel.

A real gem!. We hadn't planned to visit as we'd decided in advance to visit just a few churches to prevent our young people (14,12,10) being 'churched out'! So glad we wandered in. This totally blew us all away. The ceiling pantings are absolutely incredible. Some of the figures are so well painted they look as if they are 3D and can climb down at any time! And the false cupola is mind blowing, our children were totally enraptured with the perspectives and beauty (as were we) Not to be missed!!
Amazing!. Highlight of my trip. Beautiful ceilings and the feel of the place is just spectacular. Best when quiet in the evenings.

must see. when in rome you have to visit Sant'Ignazioits a non famous church near pantheonyou have to visit if you are interested in paintings the great Frescoes of Andrea Pozzotry to find the mark on the floorfrom that point you can see the perception on the ceiling although the ceiling is flat you ll se it as 3d
The Heaven Ceiling !. A view of the fantastic painting in the ceiling is more than a heaven view...is ART !!!The most clearly vision of an uncridible painting technic!!!

Well worth the visit.. Superb illusionary ceiling and dome paintings in Sant' Ignazio di Loyola. This Baroque era church is fascinating for the illusionary dome and ceiling painting put in place here by Andrea Pozzo, a master of optical illusion painting during his time. The reason for this was due to the church being completed without a dome back in 1685. The dome illusion painting near the altar is most impressive. When you view it from the front, it honestly appears like the inside of dome structure. You can only tell it is just an optical illusion (slanted painting) after you walk around to the side to see how the shapes take form. Further, the main nave ceiling painting is of the same nature. With a deceptive upward painting that is very beautiful to view, a unique find in the centre of Rome. We also enjoyed the nicely painted and decorated chapel, statues and wall murals found within the church, classic Baroque era stuff, some of the best on display in Rome. We enjoyed the interesting circular model of world churches found near the entrance of the church. It was fun spotting those we have been lucky enough to have visited as well as those that remain on our long list of places to visit and those we were not yet even aware of. Much remains to be learned it seems. Lastly, there is a small but creatively designed piazza directly in front of Sant'Ignazio Di Loyola that is quite attractive to look at before or after visiting the church. In addition to this lovely church and piazza, you are very near to the very good Santa Maria sopra Minerva church and the important Pantheon attraction amongst many others. Combined you can easily fill the better part of ½ or ¾ of a day in sight-seeing in this central part of Rome. Overall, we really enjoy Sant'Ignazio Di Loyola first because we are slightly biased towards Baroque churches but mainly this one scores so high because of the illusionary ceiling and dome paintings inside that are unique for Rome and very fascinating to look at.

Church of St. Ignatius Loyola: Keep Looking Towards Heaven. Rome's Church of St. Ignatius Loyola is located on a square of the same name approximately half way from the Pantheon to the Trevi Fountain. If you stand on the steps of the church and look around the square, it's like being in an opera scene. Inside the church, as you walk center aisle, keep looking at the ceiling. At a certain point you will see that the cupola or dome starts to slide. That's because it's not a dome. It's flat and the Jesuit painter Del Pozzo painted a trompe l'oeil or optical illusion. He did the same thing at the Jesuit church in Vienna, Austria, which also has a flat room. This is a nice place to take children. Also frequently free concerts take place here. You have to look at wall posters plastered around the neighborhood to see when they take place. Often the musicians come from the USA.
